commit_message:
fixes auth_ref initialization error

bug 1078589

* allow client values to be overridden, but use auth_ref if none
  available
* added tests to match this flow
* refactored tokens into test_fixtures.py file

Change-Id: I771a2dee6dedf31d883417d9b4e6e64bbb620f14

heat-metadata hence are no-longer required

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat engine : remove now-unused metadata rpc calls

Remove metadata_(list|get)* calls, as these are no longer used by
heat-metadata hence are no-longer required

Change-Id: Ia67b9f329f628e3172bba24ff1b1192e8ec18079
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Part of the patch set that enables VM's to use libvirts bridge type.

Fixes bug 1078210

The bridge will be created by Nova and not by the agent. This is the first
part for the blueprint vif-plugin-improvements

This patch supports Nova managing bridges too.

In addition to this it cleans gateway code no longer used.

Change-Id: Ia621ba5edd12d8eb7ea412a2993fea43189bd511

I have tried to think about a case where out-of-pool IPs should be held for some time before being recycled.

I did not find any strong case. One might argue that there might be a lag between recycling in Quantum DB and actual removal from the VIF which is using it. However, since the latter part of this process is not managed by quantum anyway, holding IPs for a while will hardly be beneficial.

However, this would also be outside the scope of this patch.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-15 13:59:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 1736, 'date': '2012-11-15 13:59:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

files instead.

Just one curios question, why do we duplicate cores_fraction assignment here?

            cores_fraction = instance.vcpus * 1.0 / multiprocessing.cpu_count()
            cores_fraction = (instance.flavor['vcpus'] * 1.0 /
                              multiprocessing.cpu_count())"}, {'account_id': 4573, 'date': '2012-11-14 02:01:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'm a bit confused why do we want to have the vcpu count when caculating the CPU utilization?

Per my understanding, the cpu utilization is:
utilization = (instance_timie)/(whole CPU time) = (instance_timie) / ( physical cpu number * Elapsed time)=
(virtual vcpu number * cpu_time per vcpu + extra virtualization overhead)/ ( physical cpu number * Elapsed time). 

Here, I think the cpu_info['cpu_time'] is the "instance_time", i.e. it includes all vCPU's time, so we don't need the vcpu number anymomre.

Further more, even if we want to get the vcpu number, I think the cpu_info['num_cpu']  provided such information already, why do we get it from the flavor?

Please forgive me if I missed anything.'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-15 11:56:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@yunhong-jiang

Thanks for the input!

I've implemented your suggestions in:

  https://review.openstack.org/16079

Cheers,
Eoghan"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 20:25:44.000000000', 'message': "Determine instance cores from public flavors API

Fixes bug 1078371

Previously the flavor vcpus used in the CPU utilization metering
was available from the nova DB instance representation.

Now that we retrieve the on-host instances from the public nova API
as opposed to the DB, we need to retrieve the flavor vcpus from
the flavors API.

Note that it's a known issue with nova that a flavor associated
with a running instance can be deleted and re-created with the
same ID but a different resource configuration (in this case, a
different number of cores would led to an incorrect CPU util
calculation). This will be addressed in a future nova patch.

Change-Id: I093acb94a4818f671782a3cb4e2c846f29b8cec5
"}]
commit_message:
Determine instance cores from public flavors API

Fixes bug 1078371

Previously the flavor vcpus used in the CPU utilization metering
was available from the nova DB instance representation.

Now that we retrieve the on-host instances from the public nova API
as opposed to the DB, we need to retrieve the flavor vcpus from
the flavors API.

Note that it's a known issue with nova that a flavor associated
with a running instance can be deleted and re-created with the
same ID but a different resource configuration (in this case, a
different number of cores would led to an incorrect CPU util
calculation). This will be addressed in a future nova patch.

Change-Id: I093acb94a4818f671782a3cb4e2c846f29b8cec5

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

The reason disable_interspersed_args() was added is explained in I3ecb7dc1

I wonder would it be possible to re-write nova-manage to use argparse subparsers - that should be enough to remove the need for disable_interspersed_args()

To support this in cfg, we'd just need to add:

  class ConfigOpts(object):
      ...
      def.add_cli_subparsers(self, **kwargs):
          return self._oparser.add_subparsers(**kwargs)

Would you be able to confirm that nova-manage will work using sub-parsers?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

I haven't put to much thought into it yet Laurence, but I'm thinking that argparse is a good CLI parsing API and there's no need for us to replicate that

cfg is there mostly to unify CLI and config file parsing, but for sub-commands you only care about CLI parsing ... so allowing people to add sub-parses using the argparse API seems appropriate to me"}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 15.'}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Got it.

I will make it run as you suggested, though that might break some basic logic of 'cfg', such as method of option registering between 'cfg' and argparse, e.g.


cfg.register_opt(StrOpt('foo'))

v.s.

parser.add_argument('--foo', type=int, help='foo help')

what's more, cfg._oparser does persist between __call__, which makes add_subparsers hard to coexist with current 'cfg' logic."}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 15:

hi guys,

disable_interspersed_args is not yet supported by argparse, please refer to: http://bugs.python.org/issue13966

so, test case for disable_interspersed_args is comment out by me for happiness of tox.

shall we comment it out as i did, or just leave it failed for further integration of disable_interspersed_args in argparse?'}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

Hi Mark,

Thank you for your explanation, it is now quite clear to me about the usage of disable_interspersed_args feature.

But, I am considering another approach to support subcommand requirements, now that we agreed to introduce new subcommand support rather than disable_interspersed_args ugly style.

That is, what if we introduce a CommandGroup class, to make it more general to represent subcommand feature.
It looks like:
------------------
cfg = CommonConfigOpts()

subcmd_grp_foo = CommandGroup('foo')
subcmd_grp_foo.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('blar4foo'))

subcmd_grp_bar = CommandGroup('bar')
subcmd_grp_bar.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('blar4bar'))

subcmd_grp_foo.register_commandgroup(subcmd_grp_bar)
cfg.register_commandgroup(subcmd_grp_foo)

cfg(['foo', '--blar4foo', 'fooblar', 'bar', '--blar4bar', 'barblar'])

assertTrue(cfg.foo.blar4foo, 'fooblar')
assertTrue(cfg.foo.bar.blar4bar, 'barblar')
--------------

This way, we got a more intuitive/general vision of subcommand feature, and argparse api would not expose to the 'openstack.common.cfg' users."}, {'account_id': 5727, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

pseudo code corrupted, resubmit,

cfg = CommonConfigOpts()

subcmd_grp_foo = CommandGroup('foo') 

subcmd_grp_foo.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('blar4foo'))

subcmd_grp_bar = CommandGroup('bar')

subcmd_grp_bar.register_cli_opt(StrOpt('blar4bar'))

subcmd_grp_foo.register_commandgroup(subcmd_grp_bar) 

cfg.register_commandgroup(subcmd_grp_foo)

cfg(['foo', '--blar4foo', 'fooblar', 'bar', '--blar4bar', 'barblar'])

assertTrue(cfg.foo.blar4foo, 'fooblar')

assertTrue(cfg.foo.bar.blar4bar, 'barblar')"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 16: Doesn't seem to work

commit_message:
argparse support for cfg

* openstack/common/cfg.py
  Optparse is fading out since python 2.7, this
  patch will help openstack/common work on more
  advanded version of python(argparse).
  Now, disable_interspersed_args() has no effect.
  Added new method add_cli_subparsers, return
  argparse  subparser, for  usages  such  as
  subcommand.

* tests/unit/test_cfg.py
  SubcommandTestCase added.
  Disabled test_disable_interspersed_args test entry
  for happiness of tox, temporarily.
  Modified test_help for port of argparse.

* tools/pip-requires
  include argparse module for python 2.6

Change-Id: Ie5cbde1a92a92786d64dea0ddfcfbf288c29f960

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 16:13:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

The RPC API change is a problem, see http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-stable-maint/2012-November/000007.html

Anyone got ideas on how this could be fixed on stable without the RPC API change? e.g. do we really need the volume_id to detect that this name has been allocated?"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-01 16:32:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I find it hard to believe that we can't detect a device name is reserved from the instance_uuid/device_name mapping we're creating in Folsom

Dunno, would something like this work:

 @@ -108,13 +108,11 @@ def instance_block_mapping(instance, bdms):
          if bdm['no_device']:
              continue
 
 -        # ebs volume case
 -        if (bdm['volume_id'] or bdm['snapshot_id']):
 -            ebs_devices.append(bdm['device_name'])
 -            continue
 -
          virtual_name = bdm['virtual_name']
          if not virtual_name:
 +            # ebs volume case
 +            # if (bdm['volume_id'] or bdm['snapshot_id']):
 +            ebs_devices.append(bdm['device_name'])
              continue

commit_message:
Fix reserve_block_device_name while attach volume

The block device name will not  be reserved in current implementation
due to missing volume_id in block_device_mapping. This will cause
block_device.instance_block_mapping does not return the ebs device
which should be reserved.

This patch adds the volume_id to block_device_mapping while reserving
block device name.

Fixes bug 1062033

(Similar to dcabd6159abcdccd99e55495ec005926465007a8 and
66f1a34cabc26930db2a1afed5a0f5ced4d1c015 which fixed the issue in
trunk)

Change-Id: I8f08b568619fefa99850de0bee7d605749d53b0a

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-15 11:03:07.000000000', 'message': 'heat workaround for HA/Autoscaling regression

Interim workaround for HA/Autoscaling regression, caused by change of
scope for stack_get_by_name to be per-tenant, meaning we need to do a
brute-force lookup to find the stack entry when using the stored admin
context.

A better, more comprehensive (but more intrusive) fix is in-progress
but this at least returns us to the same functionality we had before

Note this means that all stacks using WatchRule still need to have names
unique accross all tenants.

bug 1078779

Change-Id: Iad1830d38262d1afb63cee16a3e366d9fd09acb4
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
heat workaround for HA/Autoscaling regression

Interim workaround for HA/Autoscaling regression, caused by change of
scope for stack_get_by_name to be per-tenant, meaning we need to do a
brute-force lookup to find the stack entry when using the stored admin
context.

A better, more comprehensive (but more intrusive) fix is in-progress
but this at least returns us to the same functionality we had before

Note this means that all stacks using WatchRule still need to have names
unique accross all tenants.

bug 1078779

Change-Id: Iad1830d38262d1afb63cee16a3e366d9fd09acb4
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix a logic error in stable version calculation.

Milestone information in blank for stable branches, so there is no milestone
prefix. However, we were blindly concatenating the milestone version
prefix onto the datestamp.

Fixes bug 1059634.

(cherry picked from commit b87960426a)

Change-Id: I6cff4ee7f6c1dc970397b66fd2d15fa22b0a63a3

/bib/sh.

If an option has a dash in it and is required, the check fails because it
tries to self._get() on the name (with dash) rather than the dest (with
underscore).

'}]
commit_message:
cfg: fix required if option has a dash

If an option has a dash in it and is required, the check fails because it
tries to self._get() on the name (with dash) rather than the dest (with
underscore).

(cherry picked from commit aca1805d91)

Change-Id: I6448019f70f98bc2e58a325d0cf9ce88b8bb085b
Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

commit_message:
Adjust the logging_context_format_string.

This patch fixed the bug 1078190.

The 'logging_context_format_string' option uses some undefined fields
in log.ContextAdapter() and context.RequestContext(), which would
result a 'KeyError' exception when calling logging functions.

Change-Id: I41ee8a9ac89079c30e970477730c8615fb4636b7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-14 15:49:30.000000000', 'message': 'Enable eventlet_backdoor to return port.

Instead of having no return initialize_if_enabled() will now
return the port being used for the backdoor. This will allow
the use of random ports (which is set with a backdoor_port
configuration option set to 0)

This will also enable nova to be able to switch to using the
version of eventlet_backdoor here instead of the copy in
nova.common which will require this change in nova.

Change-Id: I01b6966daba410d82281ba86b5d295313ec36c68
'}]
commit_message:
Enable eventlet_backdoor to return port.

Instead of having no return initialize_if_enabled() will now
return the port being used for the backdoor. This will allow
the use of random ports (which is set with a backdoor_port
configuration option set to 0)

This will also enable nova to be able to switch to using the
version of eventlet_backdoor here instead of the copy in
nova.common which will require this change in nova.

Change-Id: I01b6966daba410d82281ba86b5d295313ec36c68

commit_message:
Fixes snapshot instance failure on libvirt.

Fixed the failure during snapshotting instance (on libvirt) due to incorrect
attribute access.

Fixes LP: #1075556

Change-Id: I079467d38aef5071488084f9bfa080a2a5af2609

The database code is separated from the rest: APIs, models and migration scripts. This is probably the best for initial development. Moving forward is this still the plan? On the plus side, it does provide better modularity of the data layer though.

Questions and comments inline, mostly nits and coding styles except the state transition. Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 2243, 'date': '2012-08-08 02:56:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (2 inline comments)

This is awesome Mikyung (et all)... It's a huge patch, I'll come back to it again but first pass through it looks good so far."}, {'account_id': 1779, 'date': '2012-08-08 11:07:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This commit message is terrible, it offers no description of what is being done here. Linking to a blueprint is not a substitute for describing a change. For further guidance on writing commit messages refer to:

http://wiki.openstack.org/GitCommitMessages#Information_in_commit_messages

I also really think that a change of this magnitude should be split up into a series of discrete patches. There is a whole heap of code restructuring/reformatting here mixed in with functional changes, which make review of such a large change impractical IMHO. See also

http://wiki.openstack.org/GitCommitMessages#Structural_split_of_changes"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-08 16:43:11.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

I agree that smaller patches would be much easier to review, but in this case I think ISI is the 'only' user of the baremetal code, because it only supports Tilera architechture and there aren't really users of that sitting around. I therefore don't think regression risk should be a concern.

I do agree that If it is possible to split this up to make it easier to review that would be amazing."}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-09 15:35:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-09 15:48:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

It seems very strange to have it where it is, separate from nova.db.sqlalchemy.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-14 21:20:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Disregard my comment... I had an old screen up before this database piece was put in a separate, smaller patch and before the commit message was updated... apologies.'}, {'account_id': 7, 'date': '2012-08-14 21:37:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(11 inline comments)

Off to a good start, but I have a number of suggestions for readability and shrinking file names inline.

best,

-jay"}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-15 13:45:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: Do not merge

I'm very surprised to see the baremetal driver adding it's own SQL database.

I don't like us adding a new database because of the code duplication, extra config settings, setup tools and complexity involved. It also introduces difficulties around taking a consistent backup of two databases at once.

I really don't see a compelling reason why not to just add new tables to the Nova database?

If you think this is really important for the baremetal driver and justified, I think we should discuss further on the openstack-dev mailing list."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-15 13:51:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Is this database intended to be per-compute-node? i.e. will each compute node have a different database? That would change things a little, as it is more analogous to libvirt's database

How do you run db_sync for this database?"}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-08-15 14:04:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: (2 inline comments)

'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:39:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Vish and I discussed the DB issue a little on IRC

Even if it was ok for drivers to add a new shared database (I don't think it is ok, Vish thinks it is) we still want to move away from compute nodes sharing a database because of the problems it causes for upgrades - see https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/no-db-compute

I haven't looked in enough detail to tell, but I suspect this data could be stored in a separate DB per-compute node

As an example of what I mean:

    def list_instances(self):
        for node in bmdb.bm_node_get_all(service_host=FLAGS.host):

i.e. we're querying this shared database and filtering based on the current hostname. If we had a DB dedicated to each compute node, we'd just do:

    def list_instances(self):
        for node in bmdb.bm_node_get_all():

this is analogous to libvirt:

    def list_instances(self):
        for domain_id in self._conn.listDomainsID():

here libvirt is querying its own per-host DB

Is it possible to move all this data into a per-host DB?"}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:42:23.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:45:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

@Jay Pipes: Thanks for commenting. Fixed based on your suggestions.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-15 15:56:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Doesn't seem to work

'}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-08-15 18:46:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Great, thanks. It would be good to use a different method in the scheduler as you are getting data from the baremetal database.

Do you think there is a way to do it without database access?

If not could we limit the data that it needs significantly? if so we can probably add the necessary data when we report_capabilities, or perhaps create host aggregates for the important data.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-15 19:21:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Vish and @Mark McLoughlin:

> Do you think there is a way to do it without database access?


 Our current approach has BaremetalHostManager.
It probes bare-metal nova-compute for the full capability when a bare-metal instance is requested to spawn.
Currently it is done using remote db access.
We can change it using RPC. 
Does this answer your question?


>If not could we limit the data that it needs significantly? if so we can probably add the necessary data when we report_capabilities, or perhaps create host aggregates for the important data.

Aggregated capability can be as big as N-tuples of the current capability. We can reduce its size. But, periodic updating of the aggregated capability seems to  waste of network bandwidth and CPU time of a bare-metal nova-compute.

And another issue:

As David sent an email to openstack-dev mailing list, how about having a single (shared) bare-metal db for bare-metal nova-compute? The db can be put on a bare-metal nova-compute or any other node. That approach is good for backing up the db, and for registration/deletion of new/old bare-metal nodes from the cloud.'}, {'account_id': 221, 'date': '2012-08-16 19:19:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Based on openstack-dev mails, this separate (shared) bare-metal database will be used by bare-metal nova-compute. The scheduler wouldn't need access to the bare-metal database at all. Please review this db code as-is.

Based on that, we'll update other patch sets while considering:

a) We'll update bare-metal driver code to return a list of host states instead of just one. (Patch Set #3)

b) We'll update host_manager to handle the received capabilities of bare-metal provision. (Patch Set #4)

c) We'll make sure that instance_type matches what the node has and the used ones. (Patch Set #3 and #4)

d) Minor updates on Docs (Patch Set #2) and Scripts (Patch Set #5)

So, please review this Patch Set #1."}, {'account_id': 2889, 'date': '2012-08-20 15:29:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(7 inline comments)

There are several small changes that should be made (ie, adding indexes to make queries faster). There is also a race condition when creating a new BM node (solution is probably simple). I am also unclear as to why the nova.db.sqlalchemy.session code is duplicated here."}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:06:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

@Devananda

The duplication of session code is for DB separation. We need to use FLAGS.baremetal_sql_connection instead of FLAGS.sql_connection in get_engine(). It is the only reason. Is there a way to do this without duplication? We use it willingly.'}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-08-20 16:22:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

Can we change the original session.py to take sql_connection as a parameter?

Like:
def get_session(sql_connection=None)
    if not sql_connection:
        sql_connection = FLAGS.sql_connection
    ...'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-08-20 19:49:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: No score

but then realized it is a bit more complicated. I will update it with another solution later tonight.

Does your current code work with >1 database connection? I think that the _ENGINE and _MAKER singletons would prevent actually connecting to more than 1 database back end, no?'}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-08-21 02:29:14.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

[{'created': '2012-08-02 17:46:25.000000000', 'message': 'Implements blueprint General Bare-Metal Provisioning Framework

'}, {'created': '2012-08-02 17:56:31.000000000', 'message': 'Implements blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>

'}, {'created': '2012-08-03 12:52:58.000000000', 'message': 'Implements blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
'}, {'created': '2012-08-09 15:35:34.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 1 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Previously bare-metal provisioning used text file to store information of
bare-metal machines. Now, MySQL database is used to keep the information of
bare-metal machines. The database is designed to support pxe/non-pxe
booting methods, heterogeneous hypervisor types, and architectures.
Using MySQL database makes maintenance and upgrade easier than text files.

The database for bare-metal machines is implemented as a separate database
from main nova database. And the database can reside any machine.
The location of the database and its server needs to be specified as a flag
in the nova.conf file as is the case of glance.

There are a couple of reasons for this approach.
First, the information needed for bare-metal machines are different from the
information needed for non-bare-metal machines. By having separate database
for bare-metal machines, we can customize the database without affecting
main nova database.
Second, fault-tolerance can be embedded at bare-metal nova-compute level.
Since one bare-metal nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal nodes,
fault-tolerance of a bare-metal nova-compute node is quite important.
With a separate database for bare-metal machines, fault-tolerance can be
achieved independently from main nova database.
Replication of the bare-metal database and implementation of fault-tolerance
themselves are not part of this patch.

Implementation-wise, it models nova/db as much as possible.

The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this database.
The patches of bare-metal driver will be proposed and reviewed
after this patch is merged into upstream.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
'}, {'created': '2012-08-09 17:43:43.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5

'}, {'created': '2012-08-13 18:24:18.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 1 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Previously, bare-metal provisioning used text files to store information of
bare-metal machines. In this patch, a MySQL database is used to store the
information. The database is designed to support pxe/non-pee
booting methods, heterogeneous hypervisor types, and architectures.
Using a MySQL database makes maintenance and upgrades easier than
using text files.

The database for bare-metal machines is implemented as a separate database
from the main nova database. The database can be on any machine.
The location of the database and its server need to be specified as a flag
in the nova.conf file (as in the case of glance).

There are a couple of reasons for this approach.
First, the information needed for bare-metal machines is different from that
for non-bare-metal machines. With a separate database
for bare-metal machines, the database can be customized without affecting
the main nova database.

Second, fault-tolerance can be embedded in bare-metal nova-compute.
Since a single instance of bare-metal nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal
nodes, fault-tolerance of a bare-metal nova-compute node is very important.
With a separate database for bare-metal machines, fault-tolerance can be
achieved independently from the main nova database.

Replication of the bare-metal database and implementation of fault-tolerance
are not part of this patch.

The implementation models nova and its database as much as possible.

The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this database.
The patches of the bare-metal driver will be proposed
after this patch is merged upstream.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>

'}, {'created': '2012-08-15 15:42:23.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 1 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Previously, bare-metal provisioning used text files to store information of
bare-metal machines. In this patch, a MySQL database is used to store the
information. The database is designed to support pxe/non-pee
booting methods, heterogeneous hypervisor types, and architectures.
Using a MySQL database makes maintenance and upgrades easier than
using text files.

The database for bare-metal machines is implemented as a separate database
from the main nova database. The database can be on any machine.
The location of the database and its server need to be specified as a flag
in the nova.conf file (as in the case of glance).

There are a couple of reasons for this approach.
First, the information needed for bare-metal machines is different from that
for non-bare-metal machines. With a separate database
for bare-metal machines, the database can be customized without affecting
the main nova database.

Second, fault-tolerance can be embedded in bare-metal nova-compute.
Since a single instance of bare-metal nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal
nodes, fault-tolerance of a bare-metal nova-compute node is very important.
With a separate database for bare-metal machines, fault-tolerance can be
achieved independently from the main nova database.

Replication of the bare-metal database and implementation of fault-tolerance
are not part of this patch.

The implementation models nova and its database as much as possible.

The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this database.
The patches of the bare-metal driver will be proposed
after this patch is merged upstream.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

'}, {'created': '2012-10-01 20:26:47.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 2 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

Previously, bare-metal provisioning used text files to store information of
bare-metal machines. In this patch, a MySQL is used to store the information.
The DB is designed to support PXE/non-PXE booting methods,
heterogeneous hypervisor types, and architectures. Using a MySQL makes
maintenance and upgrades easier than using text files. The DB for
bare-metal nodes is implemented as a separate DB from the main Nova DB.
The DB can be on any machines/places. The location of the DB and its server
needs to be specified as a flag in the nova.conf file (as in the case of glance).
There are a couple of reasons for this approach.
First, the information needed for bare-metal nodes is different from
that for non-bare-metal nodes. With a separate database for bare-metal nodes,
the database can be customized without affecting the main Nova DB.
Second, fault tolerance can be embedded in bare-metal nova-compute.
Since one bare-metal nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal nodes,
fault tolerance of a bare-metal nova-compute node is very important.
With a separate DB for bare-metal nodes, fault-tolerance can be achieved
independently from the main Nova DB. Replication of the bare-metal DB
and implementation of fault-tolerance are not part of this patch.
The implementation models nova and its DB as much as possible.
The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this DB.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

'}, {'created': '2012-10-03 21:54:01.000000000', 'message': 'Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 2 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

In baremetal provisioning, one nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal machines.
A bare-metal machine does not run openstack at all.
Previously, bare-metal provisioning used text files to store information of
bare-metal machines. In this patch, a MySQL database is used to store the information.
We target only MySQL database. The DB is designed to support PXE/non-PXE booting methods,
heterogeneous hypervisor types, and architectures. Using a MySQL database makes
maintenance and upgrades easier than using text files. The DB for
bare-metal machines is implemented as a separate DB from the main Nova DB.
The DB can be on any machines/places. The location of the DB and its server
needs to be specified as a flag in the nova.conf file (as in the case of glance).
There are a couple of reasons for this approach.
First, the information needed for bare-metal machines is different from
that for non-bare-metal machines. With a separate database for bare-metal machines,
the database can be customized without affecting the main Nova DB.
Second, fault tolerance can be embedded in nova-compute.
Since one nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal machines,
fault tolerance of a nova-compute node is very important.
With a separate DB for bare-metal machines, fault-tolerance can be achieved
independently from the main Nova DB. Replication of the bare-metal DB
and implementation of fault-tolerance are not part of this patch.
The implementation models nova and its DB as much as possible.
The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this DB.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

Since one nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal machines,
fault tolerance of a nova-compute node is very important.
With a separate DB for bare-metal machines, fault-tolerance can be achieved
independently from the main Nova DB. Replication of the bare-metal DB
and implementation of fault-tolerance are not part of this patch.
The implementation models nova and its DB as much as possible.
The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this DB.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

commit_message:
Added separate bare-metal MySQL DB.

Part 2 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework

In baremetal provisioning, one nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal
machines. A bare-metal machine does not run openstack at all.
Previously, bare-metal provisioning used text files to store information
of bare-metal machines. In this patch, a MySQL database is used to store
the information. We target only MySQL database. The DB is designed to
support PXE/non-PXE booting methods, heterogeneous hypervisor types, and
architectures. Using a MySQL database makes maintenance and upgrades
easier than using text files. The DB for bare-metal machines is
implemented as a separate DB from the main Nova DB. The DB can be on any
machines/places. The location of the DB and its server needs to be
specified as a flag in the nova.conf file (as in the case of glance).
There are a couple of reasons for this approach. First, the information
needed for bare-metal machines is different from that for non-bare-metal
machines. With a separate database for bare-metal machines, the database
can be customized without affecting the main Nova DB. Second, fault
tolerance can be embedded in nova-compute. Since one nova-compute
manages multiple bare-metal machines, fault tolerance of a nova-compute
node is very important. With a separate DB for bare-metal machines,
fault-tolerance can be achieved independently from the main Nova DB.
Replication of the bare-metal DB and implementation of fault-tolerance
are not part of this patch. The implementation models nova and its DB as
much as possible. The bare-metal driver must be upgraded to use this DB.

Change-Id: I7b7ba1903a672a50c567f95fc6554d119463b0c5
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

subject: Installation on openSUSE and SUSE Linux Enterprise Server
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-09 12:07:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15721/1/check/gate-openstack-manuals-merge/1148 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:04:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Thinking aloud in reviews... if we include these, we have to exclude all Compute/Image/Volume installation instructions because it is only for Object Storage. Is there a better way to accomplish what we want (instructions for installing Object Storage on SLES?)'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:17:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:17:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15721/2/check/gate-openstack-manuals-merge/1196 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:20:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Fixed typo (available) in latest patch set.

Anne, I'm not sure about your comment. The installation of the Object Storage on Ubuntu is described in openstack-install/object-storage-install-ubuntu.xml. That's why I added the instructions as openstack-install/object-storage-install-opensuse-and-sles.xml.

Why do we have to exclude all Compute/Image/Volume installation instructions if we add instructions for installing the Object Storage? The added file is only used in the "OpenStack Object Storage Administration Manual".'}, {'account_id': 964, 'date': '2012-11-12 20:08:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Hi Christian - 
Sorry I didn't explain myself very well. 

The way that the install guide is built means that all instructions are included plus only the conditional text (in your case, the two-three elements tagged os="sles;opensuse") -- so all info about installing Compute/Image/Identity will still be included. Since your packages don't include Compute/Image/Identity (that I can tell), I was thinking we might want to put your added content into a new location. 

Here's what indicates what gets built in the pom.xml for local builds:

<properties>
        <!-- This is set by Jenkins according to the branch. -->
        <release.path.name>local</release.path.name>
        <comments.enabled>1</comments.enabled>
        <operating.system>yum</operating.system>
        <!-- This is set by Jenkins to run twice for each similar
operating system group -->
        <profile.os>centos;fedora;rhel</profile.os>
    </properties>

What happens next is that the Jenkins build files
/modules/openstack_project/files/jenkins_job_builder/config/manuals.yaml needs to have a third build job with these "goals" -

-Doperating.system=zypper -Dprofile.os=sles;opensuse
-Drelease.path.name=${DOC_RELEASE_PATH}
-Dcomments.enabled=${DOC_COMMENTS_ENABLED}

However if you build with zypper for the "operating.system" and sles;opensuse for the "profile.os" then all non-conditional elements will also be included. I don't think that's what we want. 

If we want a third guide with SLES and OpenSuse instructions, we'll need instructions for Compute/Image/Identity/Volumes as well I believe. Is that not far behind?

Let me know if this explanation makes sense. 

Thanks again for the contribution - let's get it placed so that the publication makes sense and reaches people.'}, {'account_id': 167, 'date': '2012-11-15 08:17:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Abandoned

We moved the Swift packages to an other repository. I'll recommit the change after fixing and proceeding with additions to Keystone and so on."}]

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 13:41:46.000000000', 'message': "Modified HyperV Compute driver to return the disk stats of the current instances drive

It fixes bug 1077922

The current version of the HyperV Compute driver was returning the disk stats about the C: drive always.

This patch makes HyperV driver extract the current drive from the flag 'instances_path'.

In order to optimize the procedure, the disk stats extraction is also unified in one method.

Change-Id: I4920cf2cc07d0f514c0358144b7bceb15d439a63
"}, {'created': '2012-11-12 15:21:55.000000000', 'message': "Fixed HyperV to get disk stats of instances drive

It fixes bug 1077922

The current version of the HyperV Compute driver was returning the disk stats about the C: drive always.

This patch makes HyperV driver extract the current drive from the flag 'instances_path'.

commit_message:
Fixed HyperV to get disk stats of instances drive

It fixes bug 1077922

The current version of the HyperV Compute driver was returning the disk stats about the C: drive always.

This patch makes HyperV driver extract the current drive from the flag 'instances_path'.

In order to optimize the procedure, the disk stats extraction is also unified in one method.

Change-Id: I4920cf2cc07d0f514c0358144b7bceb15d439a63

commit_message:
Adds a conf option for custom configdrive mkisofs

In order to support ConfigDrive on Hyper-V an option for supporting
a customizable mkisofs / genisoimage is needed, including optional
path.

The option "mkisofs_cmd" deafult to "genisoimage" to preserve
backwards compatibility

Change-Id: I89167bf77bddae9a0f989874ad0a972d7898a903

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-08-14 18:17:34.000000000', 'message': "Added bare-metal host manager.

Part 4 of 5: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

The bare-metal host manager supports bare-metal provisioning and
original VM provisioning. For VM provisioning, it simply calls
the original host manager. A bare-metal nova-compute may manage
multiple bare-metal machines and it's capability report is not
it's own capability but the capability of the bare-metal
machines being managed. The existing 'capability' is designed
to describe the capability of one machine, and cannot describe
the full capabilities of the multiple bare-metal machines.
So, the existing 'capability' is used to show the maximum
resource in the bare-metal machine farm.
The bare-metal host manager detects if a nova-compute is
for VM or bare-metal. For bare-metal machine provisioning,
it fetches the full capabilities of a bare-metal nova-compute
by accessing bare-metal database.
The full capabilities are to be used by the scheduler.
No changes are needed in the scheduler side.

Change-Id: Ib207f495493db99a4a6cd1ac0044662fb7397322
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
"}, {'created': '2012-10-01 21:02:14.000000000', 'message': "Added bare-metal host manager.

Part 6 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

The bare-metal host manager is used when multiple bare-metal
instances are created by one request. The bare-metal host manager
detects if a nova-compute is for VM or bare-metal.
For VM instance provisioning, it simply calls the original host_manager.
For bare-metal instance provisioning, BaremetalNodeState is used
to manage bare-metal node's resources when an instance is provisioned
to a bare-metal node.

Change-Id: Ib207f495493db99a4a6cd1ac0044662fb7397322
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>
"}, {'created': '2012-10-04 17:55:01.000000000', 'message': "Added bare-metal host manager.

Part 6 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

The bare-metal host manager is used when multiple bare-metal
instances are created by one request. The bare-metal host manager
detects if a nova-compute is for VM or bare-metal.
For VM instance provisioning, it simply calls the original host_manager.
For bare-metal instance provisioning, BaremetalNodeState is used
to manage bare-metal node's resources when an instance is provisioned
to a bare-metal node.

Change-Id: Ib207f495493db99a4a6cd1ac0044662fb7397322
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>

commit_message:
Added bare-metal host manager.

Part 6 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

The bare-metal host manager is used when multiple bare-metal
instances are created by one request. The bare-metal host manager
detects if a nova-compute is for VM or bare-metal.
For VM instance provisioning, it simply calls the original host_manager.
For bare-metal instance provisioning, BaremetalNodeState is used
to manage bare-metal node's resources when an instance is provisioned
to a bare-metal node.

Change-Id: Ib207f495493db99a4a6cd1ac0044662fb7397322
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

[{'created': '2012-11-01 03:49:29.000000000', 'message': 'Check instance_type in compute capability filter

Currently the compute filter checkes if instance_type is None, I think this
check should be done by compute capability filter. After all, compute filter
only filter if compute is enabled or not, has nothing to do with instance type.

I assume this should be left in changeset 0c704cd87c094a37188ec, which split
compute capability filter from compute filter.

Change-Id: I391615114bd9d9359eeb0b2b3642dcec86a8285e
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

commit_message:
Check instance_type in compute capability filter

Instance type is guaranteed to exist and not be None or empty dict
as a quite a while ago, although it used to be that prep_resize
didn't have it.

Remove the checking for instance_type.

Change-Id: I391615114bd9d9359eeb0b2b3642dcec86a8285e
Signed-off-by: Yunhong, Jiang <yunhong.jiang@intel.com>

'}, {'created': '2012-11-13 23:05:23.000000000', 'message': "Refactor scheduling weights.

This makes scheduling weights more plugin friendly and creates shared
code that can be used by the host scheduler as well as the future cells
scheduler.  Weighing classes can now be specified much like you can
specify scheduling host filters.

The new weights code reversed the old behavior where lower weights win.
Higher weights are now the winners.

The least_cost module and configs have been deprecated, but are still
supported for backwards compatibility.  The code has moved to
nova.scheduler.weights.least_cost and been modified to work with the new
loadable-class code.  If any of the least_cost related config options are
specified, this least_cost weigher will be used.

For those not overriding the default least_cost config values, the new
RamWeigher class will be used.  The default behavior of the RamWeigher
class is the same default behavior as the old least_cost module.

The RamWeigher class introduces a new config option
'ram_weight_multiplier'.  The default of 1.0 causes weights equal to the
free memory in MB to be returned, thus hosts with more free memory are
preferred (causes equal spreading).  Changing this value to a negative
number such as -1.0 will cause reverse behavior (fill first).

DocImpact

Change-Id: I1e5e5039c299db02f7287f2d33299ebf0b9732ce

commit_message:
Refactor scheduling weights.

This makes scheduling weights more plugin friendly and creates shared
code that can be used by the host scheduler as well as the future cells
scheduler.  Weighing classes can now be specified much like you can
specify scheduling host filters.

The new weights code reverses the old behavior where lower weights win.
Higher weights are now the winners.

The least_cost module and configs have been deprecated, but are still
supported for backwards compatibility.  The code has moved to
nova.scheduler.weights.least_cost and been modified to work with the new
loadable-class code.  If any of the least_cost related config options are
specified, this least_cost weigher will be used.

For those not overriding the default least_cost config values, the new
RamWeigher class will be used.  The default behavior of the RamWeigher
class is the same default behavior as the old least_cost module.

The new weights code introduces a new config option
'scheduler_weight_classes' which is used to specify which weigher classes
to use.  The default is 'all classes', but modified if least_cost
deprecated config options are used, as mentioned above.

The RamWeigher class introduces a new config option
'ram_weight_multiplier'.  The default of 1.0 causes weights equal to the
free memory in MB to be returned, thus hosts with more free memory are
preferred (causes equal spreading).  Changing this value to a negative
number such as -1.0 will cause reverse behavior (fill first).

DocImpact

Change-Id: I1e5e5039c299db02f7287f2d33299ebf0b9732ce

Ah it looks like the .unittest script isn't telling nose to only look in the tests dir for tests and it considers all of ./ a valid test location.

diff --git a/.unittests b/.unittests
index b977da4..3210149 100755
--- a/.unittests
+++ b/.unittests
@@ -1,7 +1,7 @@
 #!/bin/bash
 set -e
 
-nosetests --exe --with-coverage --cover-package swiftclient --cover-erase $@
+nosetests --exe --with-coverage --cover-package swiftclient --cover-erase -w tests $@
 rvalue=$?
 rm -f .coverage
 exit $rvalue


That will also fix it, but like I said I'm cool with changing this."}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Thanks for the patch John

If a simple config change sorts out the swiftclient issue, I think we should just go with that - not excited at the prospect of updating all projects for the rename

Especially since Monty is working on what's AFAICT a replacement for this stuff - https://github.com/openstack-dev/pbr"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-15 06:03:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

commit_message:
renamed openstack/common/setup.py to common_setup.py

nose assumes that "setup.py" is a special name, and therefore
doesn't handle it well. Without this change, you will always see
an error when running the tests for python-swiftclient.

Change-Id: I30d65456bc8d1a992a4ef666b0690574739ad735

subject: Asynchronous logging
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 67, 'name': 'Vish Ishaya', 'email': 'vishvananda@gmail.com', 'username': 'vishvananda'}, {'_account_id': 159, 'name': 'Eric Windisch', 'email': 'ewindisch@docker.com', 'username': 'ewindisch'}, {'_account_id': 385, 'name': 'Jason Kölker', 'email': 'jason@koelker.net', 'username': 'jason-koelker'}, {'_account_id': 1247, 'name': 'Mark McLoughlin', 'email': 'markmc@redhat.com', 'username': 'markmc'}, {'_account_id': 1297, 'name': 'Joshua Harlow', 'email': 'jxharlow@godaddy.com', 'username': 'harlowja'}, {'_account_id': 1849, 'name': 'Joe Gordon', 'email': 'joe.gordon0@gmail.com', 'username': 'jogo'}, {'_account_id': 1998, 'name': 'andrewbogott', 'username': 'andrewbogott', 'inactive': True}, {'_account_id': 2218, 'name': 'Adam Young', 'email': 'adam@younglogic.com', 'username': 'ayoung'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Actually, no, the python logger does NOT run in a thread. I believe we'd need this patch and possibly do as swift does to monkey-patch.

What is done in swift or nova currently isn't asynchronous, even if monkey-patched. They'll trigger an eventlet switch, but the calling (co)thread will block on the logging.

This patch (potentially with the code from swift) would unblock the threads calling the logger."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Jason, for clarification, python's logging only uses the threading library for thread safety (via a lock) and to extract threading information into logs. Swift's code monkey-patches that in because they don't do a general monkey-patch early enough.

You're right, this change won't work asynchronously if monkey patching isn't done at the right time in execution. I don't think we should fix or workaround that in the log module."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

I hadn't realized that logging already uses a thread internally. It isn't very clear from the documentation, but you're right.

What swift does is an option..."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Doesn't seem to work

I've updated the patch after practical testing. This is the code on which I ran the performance benchmarks against.

Here are numbers to support the change which indicate the potential for as much as a 200% aggregate performance increase.

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2012-November/002284.html

As I say in the thread, there ARE some concerns. This is why I intend for this to be a non-default option. Perhaps I can provide more information via documentation?  At least as of the current patch contents, one big concern is that timestamps will indicate the time hitting the output, not the time the log was emitted. That is resolvable, but will also be more complex."}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (5 inline comments)

This latest patch wraps handle(), so messages will get written with the timestamp at the time the log message was created, rather than when written.

This seems to be the best compromise between wrapping the individual methods and the Handlers themselves.'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

Note that the current Jenkins failure seems to be around notifications, seems the recent rabbit/rpc notifications driver changes broke tests.

The logging tests are now working...'}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 385, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

This will still block as events are emited. Logging should already work as async-ly as it can if threading and thread are monkey patched prior to logging being imported. If we want to make sure that logging is async even if its imported prior to monkey patching then we should just do what swift does and force logging to use the eventlet thread/threading: https://github.com/openstack/swift/blob/master/swift/common/utils.py#L56'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I have to say I'm pretty skeptical about the idea - if there isn't a stdlib way of doing this (even in 3.x), it would suggest to me that it's not an issue or there are complexities we're not considering

Also, what prompted this? Any particular data showing this to be an issue? Anything which makes this an OpenStack specific issue?

A change like this warrants a mailing list thread, I think - please start one on openstack-dev

commit_message:
Asynchronous logging

Creates a thread to asynchronously
(but serially) write logs in the background.

Introduces 'logging_async' BoolOpt which
defaults to 'False'. Enable this feature
with logging_async=True.

Introduces 'logging_async_backlog' IntOpt
to specify size of queue. If queue full,
threads attempting to log will block
and will operate semi-synchronously until
the queue is no longer full. Defaults
to an unlimited-size backlog queue.

Eventlet now a dependency for common.log

Change-Id: If5fa7cf3d3fa1eca54f6f40f013af349d20108ed

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-11 18:15:01.000000000', 'message': 'Added pre_consume_hook for rpc.Service.

This fixes the collector part of the bug 1075463.

Declaring a consumer topic on the same rpc connection after the consume
thread has started would result the eventlet raise RuntimeError
exception. So all the declaring work should be done before calling
rpc.conn.consume_in_thread().

If the manager of the rpc.Service wants to declare other topic consumers
than the default ones created by rpc.Service.start(), it could define
the following hook in the manager class:

  def pre_consume_hook(self, service):
    # delcare addtional consumer topics

The service paramter is the handle to the rpc.Service instance.

Change-Id: I33a98c228d45f7716e46d40d9203188f4e827c11
'}, {'created': '2012-11-15 03:55:00.000000000', 'message': "Adopted the oslo's rpc.Service change.

This fixes the collector part of the bug 1075463.

Declaring a consumer topic on the same rpc connection after the consume
thread has started would result the eventlet raise RuntimeError
exception. So all the declaring work should be done before calling
rpc.conn.consume_in_thread().

Using the hook 'initialize_service_hook()' provided by rpc.Service in
oslo to decalre the collector's specific topic consumers before starting
the consuming thread.

Change-Id: I33a98c228d45f7716e46d40d9203188f4e827c11
"}]
commit_message:
Adopted the oslo's rpc.Service change.

This fixes the collector part of the bug 1075463.

Declaring a consumer topic on the same rpc connection after the consume
thread has started would result the eventlet raise RuntimeError
exception. So all the declaring work should be done before calling
rpc.conn.consume_in_thread().

Using the hook 'initialize_service_hook()' provided by rpc.Service in
oslo to decalre the collector's specific topic consumers before starting
the consuming thread.

Change-Id: I33a98c228d45f7716e46d40d9203188f4e827c11

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-24 06:21:45.000000000', 'message': 'Adds REST API support for Fixed IPs

This adds an extension that provides a REST API for listing all
fixed ips, reserving a fixed ip and unreserving a fixed ip. The
interface is accessed via

/v2/{tenant_id}/os-fixed-ips
/v2/{tenant_id}/os-fixed-ips/reserve
/v2/{tenant_id}/os-fixed-ips/unreserve

This forms part of the work to provide APIs for functionality currently
implemented by nova-manage that needs direct db access so nova-manage
can eventually be removed

Change-Id: I92edf4e6b74b14bb9c49d5bc0c79e40d3a496bc5
Implements: blueprint apis-for-nova-manage
'}, {'created': '2012-10-25 00:33:44.000000000', 'message': 'Adds REST API support for Fixed IPs

commit_message:
Adds REST API support for Fixed IPs

This adds an extension that provides a REST API for getting information
about a fixed ip, reserving a fixed ip and unreserving a fixed ip. The
interface is accessed via

/v2/{tenant_id}/os-fixed-ips/<ip_address> # GET ip info
/v2/{tenant_id}/os-fixed-ips/<ip_address>/action # POST reserve/unreserve ip

This forms part of the work to provide APIs for functionality currently
implemented by nova-manage that needs direct db access so nova-manage
can eventually be removed

Adds db function fixed_ip_get_by_address_detailed in order to optimise being able
to get the instance and network information for a fixed ip at the same
time as the rest of the fixed ip information

Change-Id: I92edf4e6b74b14bb9c49d5bc0c79e40d3a496bc5
Implements: blueprint apis-for-nova-manage
DocImpact

commit_message:
Fix simple db image_get to look like sqlalchemy

image_get in simple db was repeating logic that exists in helper
is_image_visible method. Also, sqlalchemy implements the same way, so
now this method behaves in both dbs.

Fixes bug 1077256

Change-Id: I5285027a24157750d7c322990aa4074e2b1087c7

commit_message:
Launch ceilometer-agent-compute with OS_xxx env.

Fixed bug 1076831.

Since ceilometer-agent-compute depends on python_novaclient to talk to
nova, we should set correct environment variables like OS_USERNAME,
OS_TENANT_NAME, etc.

Change-Id: I7f315c1d21509ef85191e54d98682b581a3cab83

'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-11-13 03:51:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

Seems okay. I think I originally put that error in there to test if anybody was doing that. Kinda lame for a responder to not specify content-length or transfer-encoding explicitly, but it's probably more trouble to track them down than try to correct for them like this."}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-13 05:50:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Oh, it's even better than that. Eventlet adds the Transfer-Encoding header whenever there's no Content-Length header. That's the only criterion it uses. If you've already got a Transfer-Encoding header set, well, now you've got two.

There's a bug report (for Swift, coincidentally) of this behavior with a proposed Eventlet fix in Red Hat's bug tracker:

https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=854653

I tested this patch with curl and tcpdump, and I can confirm that the above bug is not true; there was only one Transfer-Encoding header sent. However, when I patched swob to set 

 resp.headers['transfer-encoding'] = chunked

then I saw duplicate Transfer-Encoding headers being sent."}, {'account_id': 1179, 'date': '2012-11-13 07:26:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-15 00:18:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: No score

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 23:09:30.000000000', 'message': 'Fix 500 on GET of many-segment manifest.

The proxy_logging middleware was asserting that the response contained
either a Content-Length header or a Transfer-Encoding header. If not,
it would either add one (if app_iter was a list) or blow up
(otherwise). This blowing up is observable on a GET request to a
manifest object that references more than
swift.common.constraints.CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments.

If a response makes it up to eventlet.wsgi without a Content-Length
header, then a "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" header is automatically
stuffed into the response by eventlet. Therefore, it's not an error
for a response to not have a Content-Length header, and proxy_logging
should just let it happen.

Fixes bug 1078113.

Change-Id: I3751a8ae14dc68bab546f2746b61267a5115e252
'}]
commit_message:
Fix 500 on GET of many-segment manifest.

The proxy_logging middleware was asserting that the response contained
either a Content-Length header or a Transfer-Encoding header. If not,
it would either add one (if app_iter was a list) or blow up
(otherwise). This blowing up is observable on a GET request to a
manifest object that references more than
swift.common.constraints.CONTAINER_LISTING_LIMIT segments.

If a response makes it up to eventlet.wsgi without a Content-Length
header, then a "Transfer-Encoding: chunked" header is automatically
stuffed into the response by eventlet. Therefore, it's not an error
for a response to not have a Content-Length header, and proxy_logging
should just let it happen.

Fixes bug 1078113.

Change-Id: I3751a8ae14dc68bab546f2746b61267a5115e252

commit_message:
Return 403 on images you can see but can't modify

Visible images return 404 (Not Found) when you try to modify them and
are not allowed. This patch changes this return to 403 Forbidden which
more accurately reflects the situation, in light of the fact that we are
not trying to hide the existence of the image in this case.

Fixes bug 1078520

Change-Id: I70e6e273aeaef51dad40cf001308d3a817bdced5

commit_message:
Refactor scheduling filters

This changes the scheduling filters to use the code in nova/loadables.py
to locate filtering classes.  This also creates some base functionality
in nova/filters.py to be used by both the host scheduler and the cells
scheduler.

The scheduler_available_filters default has changed to
'nova.scheduler.filters.all_filters' which is better named compared to
the old setting of 'standard_filters'.  The old method is still
supported for those that have put it explicitly in their configs, but
it's marked as deprecated.

DocImpact

Change-Id: I84fdeafdba0275ab4b25f8857563bd7b1494bb69

commit_message:
Reduce total number of fixtures

Fixtures are created before every test, so each fixture adds a
considerable amount of overhead to the overall test suite.

This patch attempts to eliminate fixtures utilized by only a few tests
in favor of re-cycling as many fixtures as possible. As a result, a few
tests are refactored to depend on different fixtures.

Change-Id: Idd4dcef5e38e304d19110c61886887fb64b4d658

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-10 01:25:37.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure strings passed to librbd are not unicode

librbd rejects unicode by throwing an exception. If the location uri
was unicode, this would result in deletes failing. Convert all rbd
StoreLocation properties to ascii strings to avoid this problem.

Fixes bug #1075580
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

commit_message:
Ensure strings passed to librbd are not unicode

librbd rejects unicode by throwing an exception. If the location uri
was unicode, this would result in deletes failing. Convert all rbd
StoreLocation properties to ascii strings to avoid this problem.

Fixes bug #1075580
Signed-off-by: Josh Durgin <josh.durgin@inktank.com>

Change-Id: I445902bb1b72b8c814585f1481e6bf9e758b4e07

commit_message:
Provide credentials via ceilometer config file

Fixes bug 1076831

Previously we passed these credentials to the ceilometer central
agent via the OS_* environment variables.

Since these credentials are now needed by the compute agent also,
and have already leaked into the config file to enable the keystone
auth token middleware, we now switch over to using the config file
only and drop the environment variable usage.

Change-Id: I0298d711905a99aa5355fe034bb0e51e53b3be21

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-10 16:39:59.000000000', 'message': "Better TempAuth storage URL guessing

I know it's just TempAuth, but bug #959953 just caught my eye as
something interesting to solve.

This does a best guess on the storage URL to return for a given
request. It allows $HOST to be used in the storage URL configuration,
where $HOST will resolve to scheme://host:port. It bases the scheme
on how the server is running or on storage_url_scheme if set. The
host:port comes from the request's Host header if it exists, and
falls back to the WSGI SERVER_NAME:SERVER_PORT otherwise.

Fixes: bug #959953
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia494bcb99a04490911ee8d2cb8b12a94e77820c5
"}]
commit_message:
Better TempAuth storage URL guessing

I know it's just TempAuth, but bug #959953 just caught my eye as
something interesting to solve.

This does a best guess on the storage URL to return for a given
request. It allows $HOST to be used in the storage URL configuration,
where $HOST will resolve to scheme://host:port. It bases the scheme
on how the server is running or on storage_url_scheme if set. The
host:port comes from the request's Host header if it exists, and
falls back to the WSGI SERVER_NAME:SERVER_PORT otherwise.

Fixes: bug #959953
DocImpact

Change-Id: Ia494bcb99a04490911ee8d2cb8b12a94e77820c5

commit_message:
Fixes JavaScript count bug in tables.

When showing tables, and you had the summary, "No items to display",
the counter at table footer says "Displaying 1 items". This commit fixes
the inclusion of the empty line into line count.
Affected sub-pages: Instances, Volumes, Images & Snapshots, etc.

Change-Id: I24da50d506be477dffdbb0f497d88b1bd3ceacdc
(cherry picked from commit 0c85d7214e992fe83cad1f00dbeebc2f3a58d1eb)

commit_message:
Return HTTP 404 for deleted images in v2

For admin contexts, the db api will return deleted images. This patch
manually checks for deleted images in the v2 controller code to treat
these cases as if the images didn't exist.

Fixes bug 1071446

Change-Id: I33075f94e9d560a279085e2afd18c8052f57d60b

commit_message:
Add module for loading specific classes

This adds nova/loadables.py which contains code that is to be shared by
host and cell scheduling filtering and weighing.

Most of this code originated from nova/scheduler/filters/__init__.py
(which was copied from nova/api extension loading).

This makes it more generic so that it can be shared.  Note that this
functionality is quite different than the generic plugin manager that
exists in openstack-common.  That code could not be used here without
some significant changes.  It also seems pretty overkill for the
functionality required by scheduling filtering and weighing.

Change-Id: I1b217dc2bc2d1dc2235c8251318d06b46597e8f4

commit_message:
Add noseopts and replace noseargs where needed to run_test.sh

Add of noseopts to the run_tests script so users can be
able to run tests adding extra options to be passed to
nosetests.
This option is currently in keystone but not in glance.
Fixes bug 1065758

Change-Id: I7c78749adb90b126da5bd9580da6bfd7c9e1bf54

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 09:30:30.000000000', 'message': 'Fixes usage of migrate_instance_start

Because migrate_instance_start is used to remove floating ips on the source
compute node, we need send the RPC to the source compute node instead of
the dest compute node.

Fixes bug 1078207

Change-Id: Ie993548944268e1ab3af0b89e74e1b54d8137802
'}]
commit_message:
Fixes usage of migrate_instance_start

Because migrate_instance_start is used to remove floating ips on the source
compute node, we need send the RPC to the source compute node instead of
the dest compute node.

Fixes bug 1078207

Change-Id: Ie993548944268e1ab3af0b89e74e1b54d8137802

commit_message:
fix deletion of LVM backed instances

    The enumeration of the logical volumes was incorrect,
    thus causing the deletion of instances booted from them,
    to fail.

    Fixes bug: 1078085

Change-Id: Ib899754002cea28f310b042e5d4a7f89416e031e
Cherry-picked: 3c9e48d1119b77428346680c2a009c44ff9bf2ce

[{'created': '2012-11-14 19:58:48.000000000', 'message': 'Actually validate properties of resources

Properties.validate() returns an error on failure; it does not raise an
exception (and never has). So we should look at the return value when we
call it.

Change-Id: Iaa0deb9f54055b4b1f73c0b37d26f5ac2c00d683
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Actually validate properties of resources

Properties.validate() returns an error on failure; it does not raise an
exception (and never has). So we should look at the return value when we
call it.

Change-Id: Iaa0deb9f54055b4b1f73c0b37d26f5ac2c00d683
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Make sure instance data is always refreshed

Fixes bug 1078793

When updating an instance's instance_type_id, the 'instance_type' joined
to the instance is not updated.  This updates that.  A DB API test is added
that failed before and passes now.

Also: Some cases of passing stale instance data within resize_instance()
and finish_resize() were found and addressed.

Change-Id: If335cc286a71597d3100425080e51c75aeec7a50

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 05:35:40.000000000', 'message': 'Fixed instance deletion issue from Nova API.

When host Compute is down, Nova API deletes the resources associated with the
instance. However, since the instance is marked deleted first, the next query
to update the instance vm_state and task_state in DB fails. And instance
remains in state vm_state=ACTIVE, task_state=DELETING, deleted=True.

Fixes LP: #1074305

Change-Id: I0a4e64d180b4b2c5e398a21a62b29b7d59549a9f
(cherry picked from commit d00f09f2ebfa17b1b66ac080f4719f925e0777de)
'}]
commit_message:
Fixed instance deletion issue from Nova API.

When host Compute is down, Nova API deletes the resources associated with the
instance. However, since the instance is marked deleted first, the next query
to update the instance vm_state and task_state in DB fails. And instance
remains in state vm_state=ACTIVE, task_state=DELETING, deleted=True.

Fixes LP: #1074305

Change-Id: I0a4e64d180b4b2c5e398a21a62b29b7d59549a9f
(cherry picked from commit d00f09f2ebfa17b1b66ac080f4719f925e0777de)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-14 14:41:06.000000000', 'message': 'Use libvirt num_cpu for CPU utilization calculation.

Previously we used the vcpus count for the corresponding flavor,
but this can be incorrect if the instance type was deleted and
re-created with a different number of cores after the instance
was booted.

Also the total number of CPUs on-host is dropped from the formula
as this is not relevant to the CPU util for the instance.

Change-Id: I23e2ad30696f11f413fd1570fe85c3a12fb0bf1e
'}]
commit_message:
Use libvirt num_cpu for CPU utilization calculation.

Previously we used the vcpus count for the corresponding flavor,
but this can be incorrect if the instance type was deleted and
re-created with a different number of cores after the instance
was booted.

Also the total number of CPUs on-host is dropped from the formula
as this is not relevant to the CPU util for the instance.

Change-Id: I23e2ad30696f11f413fd1570fe85c3a12fb0bf1e

commit_message:
Fix VM deletion from down compute node

* free network resources
* free volume resources
* delete.start and delete.stop notifications added
* Handle network deallocate in multi_host mode

Fixes bug 1067214

Co-authored-by: Vishvananda Ishaya <vishvananda@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I0d4a7dc5836d39e405824528de214f23b214849f
(cherry picked from commit 3dff43356619b4a935a5f395b066e96e8856bb4f)

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 00:19:18.000000000', 'message': 'create_db_entry_for_new_instance did not call sgh for default

When an instance is launched create_db_entry_for_new_instance() is
called which calls self.db.instance_create(). Then,
db.security_group_ensure_default() is called which creates the
default security group entry in the nova db. Though the sgh handler was
not called. Alternatively, if any nova secgroup-* call is made the sgh
is called which creates the default security group. This patch adds
a call to ensure_default() before db.instance_create() so the sgh
is called. Fixes a case missed in  bug 1050982

Change-Id: I9649b5ef026ca18a55abfb66e87fd0e358eba6f2
'}]
commit_message:
create_db_entry_for_new_instance did not call sgh for default

When an instance is launched create_db_entry_for_new_instance() is
called which calls self.db.instance_create(). Then,
db.security_group_ensure_default() is called which creates the
default security group entry in the nova db. Though the sgh handler was
not called. Alternatively, if any nova secgroup-* call is made the sgh
is called which creates the default security group. This patch adds
a call to ensure_default() before db.instance_create() so the sgh
is called. Fixes a case missed in  bug 1050982

Change-Id: I9649b5ef026ca18a55abfb66e87fd0e358eba6f2

commit_message:
Add call to trigger_instance[add/remove]_security_group_refresh quantum

The calls to trigger_instance[add/remove]_security_group_refresh were
not being called in quantumv2/api. This patch adds those calls.
Fixes bug 1057069

Change-Id: Ia76d37ebf2546a26f893dcbc8d5a05f02324ad6b

[{'created': '2012-10-26 10:32:35.000000000', 'message': 'Consistent Rollback for instance creation failures

Fixes Bug 1065092

Adds a single QUOTA.rollback for all exceptions rather than performing
the rollback individually. Ensures that no stale "reservations" are left
in place after a failed instance creation.

Change-Id: I354726b651ae8feb6153d5865e0b14b54c73314b
'}]
commit_message:
Consistent Rollback for instance creation failures

Fixes Bug 1065092

Adds a single QUOTA.rollback for all exceptions rather than performing
the rollback individually. Ensures that no stale "reservations" are left
in place after a failed instance creation.

Change-Id: I354726b651ae8feb6153d5865e0b14b54c73314b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-14 04:43:33.000000000', 'message': "Make resource tracker uses faster DB query

Fixes bug 1060363

db.instance_get_all_by_filters() uses a regex when filtering on host,
which will do a full table scan. A regex isn't needed and instead,
db.instance_get_all_by_host() can be used which does not impact the
performance so much.

Change-Id: I812e1d5320763e5c65232351e1e21285e04e6a4b
"}]
commit_message:
Make resource tracker uses faster DB query

Fixes bug 1060363

db.instance_get_all_by_filters() uses a regex when filtering on host,
which will do a full table scan. A regex isn't needed and instead,
db.instance_get_all_by_host() can be used which does not impact the
performance so much.

Change-Id: I812e1d5320763e5c65232351e1e21285e04e6a4b

commit_message:
Make tox.ini run pep8 checks on bin.

This updates the pep8 checks in our tox.ini file so that
we are also scanning the bin directory.

Additionally, it updates the main pep8 check so that it scans
keystone properly as well. Previously there were a bunch of files
getting skipped due to some of the pep8 pattern matching.

Change-Id: I13827f1c1e4155aa6979c10e981da5422391bf2d

Remove obsolete use_local_volumes

Reading documentation, I felt on that option, but grepping the source
everywhere saw no use at all, and removing seems to be safe.

Signed-off-by: Julien Danjou <julien@danjou.info>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 06:47:56.000000000', 'message': 'Remove unused volume API method - remove_from_compute()

remove_from_compute() method in cinder.volume.api is never used
by others and it is also broken since the interface in Nova has
been changed to remove_volume_connection(), thus it should be
removed from Cinder.

Change-Id: Ibcb2cf7f88606d9a540cc9a03b5c95990fca8c3e
'}]
commit_message:
Remove unused volume API method - remove_from_compute()

remove_from_compute() method in cinder.volume.api is never used
by others and it is also broken since the interface in Nova has
been changed to remove_volume_connection(), thus it should be
removed from Cinder.

Change-Id: Ibcb2cf7f88606d9a540cc9a03b5c95990fca8c3e
