revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-07 23:30:24.000000000', 'message': "discover extensions via entry points

Currently, nova client can only discover extensions in two ways:

1. Installing the extension in the novaclient/v1_1/contrib/ directory.
2. Installing the extension in the top-level python path or modifying
   the path to be picked up by pkgutils.iter_modules()

This patch allows a third, more flexible option of discovering
extensions via entry points. This means the extension can be
installed anywhere and entry points can be registered with python
to be picked up by pkg_resources.iter_entry_points().
To register an entry point, simply add the extension module to
the setup() call in setup.py like this:

setuptools.setup(
    name='mydistribution',
    packages=setuptools.find_packages(),
    entry_points={
        'novaclient.extension' : [
            'foo = mydistribution.mynovaclientexts.foo'
        ]
    },
)

commit_message:
discover extensions via entry points

Currently, nova client can only discover extensions in two ways:

1. Installing the extension in the novaclient/v1_1/contrib/ directory.
2. Installing the extension in the top-level python path or modifying
   the path to be picked up by pkgutils.iter_modules()

This patch allows a third, more flexible option of discovering
extensions via entry points. This means the extension can be
installed anywhere and entry points can be registered with python
to be picked up by pkg_resources.iter_entry_points().
To register an entry point, simply add the extension module to
the setup() call in setup.py like this:

setuptools.setup(
    name='mydistribution',
    packages=setuptools.find_packages(),
    entry_points={
        'novaclient.extension' : [
            'foo = mydistribution.mynovaclientexts.foo'
        ]
    },
)

Change-Id: Ic1e223a9173546131e742506897f585f4ac65767

What release is openstack-manuals master supposed to be documenting at this point? I thought it was open for grizzly...?'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:58:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Ooh, I misunderstood the original bug report. I thought this was something that changed from essex to folsom, not something that had changed (the other way) from folsom to grizzly. Dolph, can you confirm?'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-11-14 14:19:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(bear with me, this is a bit confusing...)

--os-token / --os-endpoint are:

* currently available in keystoneclient master
* were available in keystoneclient master at the time of the folsom release
* will definitely the standard by the time grizzly releases
* were *not* available in the *latest* release of the client as of the release of folsom (since clients do not follow the same release cycle of the services)

--token / --endpoint are still available (but undocumented) in keystoneclient for backwards compatibility, so there's nothing *wrong* with this change... I just want to understand when new client features should land in docs :("}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-11-14 16:14:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Dolph:

master generally contain documentation for the next release (in this case, grizzly). Docs for folsom go in the stable/folsom branch. 

So, this change should really be reverted here and put into the stable/folsom branch.

However, currently docs.openstack.org has links labeled "Folsom" that point to master (you'll see "trunk" in the urls) instead of stable/folsom (which should have "folsom" instead of "trunk"). Need to talk to Anne about this.'}, {'account_id': 321, 'date': '2012-11-14 16:25:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I created a new bug to revert this: https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-manuals/+bug/1078784'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-11-14 16:32:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Reverted

This patchset was reverted in change: Id0948b2cd94467729ee1e355c6970437ee7854d8'}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-11-14 16:34:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

"this change should really be reverted here and put into the stable/folsom branch" -> done, see: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15896/'}]

commit_message:
keystone: --os-token, --os-endpoint -> --token, --endpoint

Keystone Version Folsom uses flag "--token" instead of "--os-token" and "--endpoint" instead of "--os-endpoint"

Fixes bug 1077672

Change-Id: Ib0b080681544360ca03531a6cf4d406ad5265d7f

Failures in the other jobs should be investigated and fixed, as they usually indicate that something is wrong.'}, {'account_id': 2622, 'date': '2012-11-13 22:50:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

As for this patch set:

 * The commit message needs to say what this change is and why you're making it. Is it a simple refactoring? Is the account controller deleting the wrong key, thus leaving stale data in memcached?

* There's a double-delete going on. If it's two deletes of the same key, then take one out; it's wasteful. If it's two deletes of different keys, then figure out where the data really lives and only delete that one."}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:24:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 2185, 'date': '2012-11-14 03:30:02.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

'}, {'created': '2012-11-13 06:51:22.000000000', 'message': 'add delete the default memcache_key of account.

Change-Id: Ied116a58a2d5866ac76d75ae50f21277d66e5755
'}, {'created': '2012-11-14 03:24:34.000000000', 'message': "fix bug in deleting account memcache.

Every request of container and object will invoke account_info() or
container_info() to query the meta of account and container. The meta
will be cached in memcache with the key 'account/{$account}' or
'container/{$container}', So, if any request to update account and
container, we should delete the cache. But in the cache deletion of
account, it use the wrong key 'account/v1/{$account}'. This could lead
to inconsistency of account meta.

Change-Id: Ied116a58a2d5866ac76d75ae50f21277d66e5755
"}, {'created': '2012-11-14 06:46:23.000000000', 'message': "fix bug in deleting account memcache.

Every request of container and object will invoke account_info() or
container_info() to query the meta of account and container. The meta
will be cached in memcache with the key 'account/{$account}' or
'container/{$container}', So, if any request to update account and
container, we should delete the cache. But in the cache deletion of
account, it use the wrong key 'account/v1/{$account}'. This could lead
to inconsistency of account meta.

Change-Id: Ied116a58a2d5866ac76d75ae50f21277d66e5755
"}]
commit_message:
fix bug in deleting account memcache.

Every request of container and object will invoke account_info() or
container_info() to query the meta of account and container. The meta
will be cached in memcache with the key 'account/{$account}' or
'container/{$container}', So, if any request to update account and
container, we should delete the cache. But in the cache deletion of
account, it use the wrong key 'account/v1/{$account}'. This could lead
to inconsistency of account meta.

Change-Id: Ied116a58a2d5866ac76d75ae50f21277d66e5755

commit_message:
Isolate tests from the environment variable http_proxy.

This fixes bug 1078548.

This is done by adding a dependency on the fixtures library, which has
dedicated code for just this sort of thing, and using it in the base class.

Change-Id: I841fbf912b1a3ab43ca8c52c779d930aaf4a0e96

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 08:22:38.000000000', 'message': 'Fix QPID reconnect issues

The problem results from the eventlet monkey patching and the way in
which qpid performs the session reconnection. The solution is to have
the qpid reconnection disbaled and the common rpc code performing the
reconnection.

The time waiting between reconnections will be a multiple
of 2 starting at 1 and a maximum of 60 seconds.

This works around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I3c53211d23e4e68ed73046cb3c637662ab73b339
'}]
commit_message:
Fix QPID reconnect issues

The problem results from the eventlet monkey patching and the way in
which qpid performs the session reconnection. The solution is to have
the qpid reconnection disbaled and the common rpc code performing the
reconnection.

The time waiting between reconnections will be a multiple
of 2 starting at 1 and a maximum of 60 seconds.

This works around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I3c53211d23e4e68ed73046cb3c637662ab73b339

[{'created': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'message': 'Added pre_consume_hook for rpc.Service.

This fixes the collector part of the bug 1075463.

Declaring a consumer topic on the same rpc connection after the consume
thread has started would result the eventlet raise RuntimeError
exception. So all the declaring work should be done before calling
rpc.conn.consume_in_thread().

If the manager of a rpc.Service wants to declare topic consumers other
than the default ones created by rpc.Service.start(), it could define
the following hook in the manager class:

  def pre_consume_hook(self, service):
    #
    # Declare additional consumer topics here.
    # Params:
    #   service: handle to the rpc.Service instance.

commit_message:
Added initialize_service_hook for rpc.Service.

This fixes the collector part of the bug 1075463.

Declaring a consumer topic on the same rpc connection after the consume
thread has started would result the eventlet raise RuntimeError
exception. So all the declaring work should be done before calling
rpc.conn.consume_in_thread().

If the manager of a rpc.Service wants to declare topic consumers other
than the default ones created by rpc.Service.start(), it could define
the following hook in the manager class:

  def initialize_service_hook(self, service):
    #
    # Do initialization work after rpc connection is created and before
    # starting consuming thread.
    # Params:
    #   service: handle to the rpc.Service instance.

Change-Id: I80001c32ee4e51e394fed827c91ad5e1eb0f94dc

commit_message:
Properly list tokens with a null tenant

We store the tenant as a null value in json, so checking to see
if it exists is not sufficient. This makes the check safer, checking
for existance and not null before continuing.

Fixes bug 1078497

Change-Id: Ida1b958e5df6f93a30efae0d3f71df668751ff81

heat engine : create boto config via instance userdata

Create boto config via instance userdata, which the instance
cfntools can read instead of /etc/boto.cfg, avoids messy post
install sed-mangling in the templates

commit_message:

put on github, and this change modifies the location used in devstack.

commit_message:
heat engine : append watch server url to instance userdata

Append url for watch server to instance userdata, which avoids
post-install sed mangling in the template, and will make it easier
to transparently switch to a different metric service

Change-Id: I59b9b7efcd75d44e88ebe0a116a9ce1e3ef20c14
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Don't use OpenStack plugin in tox

This plugin provides syntax colouring of the tox output, at the cost of no
longer reporting errors in test setup (instead it just reports no tests run
-> success).

Change-Id: Idf4f71a54af6303090d464b0846e563ac3776e4a
Signed-off-by: Zane Bitter <zbitter@redhat.com>

Change-Id: I8e75facb5f1dc7e3e66493824a2da15a5b9ab311
'}, {'created': '2012-11-14 04:51:40.000000000', 'message': "Change references of /etc/ceilometer-{agent,collector}.conf to /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf

Complete the change to the global config file.

So by adding the project name to the call to cfg.CONF() we go from
the following search dirs:
cfg_dirs: ['/home/asalkeld', '/etc']
to:
cfg_dirs: ['/home/asalkeld/.ceilometer', '/home/asalkeld', '/etc/ceilometer', '/etc']

So you can end up with multiple configs loading like this:

DEBUG ceilometer.openstack.common.service [-] config file: ['/etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf', '/etc/ceilometer-collector.conf']

Change-Id: I8e75facb5f1dc7e3e66493824a2da15a5b9ab311
"}]
commit_message:
Change references of /etc/ceilometer-{agent,collector}.conf to /etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf

Complete the change to the global config file.

So by adding the project name to the call to cfg.CONF() we go from
the following search dirs:
cfg_dirs: ['/home/asalkeld', '/etc']
to:
cfg_dirs: ['/home/asalkeld/.ceilometer', '/home/asalkeld', '/etc/ceilometer', '/etc']

So you can end up with multiple configs loading like this:

DEBUG ceilometer.openstack.common.service [-] config file: ['/etc/ceilometer/ceilometer.conf', '/etc/ceilometer-collector.conf']

Change-Id: I8e75facb5f1dc7e3e66493824a2da15a5b9ab311

yeah, we already have several plugins that are essentially "proxies" between two APIs (NVP, NEC, Ryu), so I agree that a more specific name indicating the API being proxied to would make sense.'}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thanks Akihiro, Mark. We based this plugin on the NB APIs exposed by FloodLight which is fairly widely used in the open source community and the API itself is very generic in nature. It is also our hope that this plugin will be a helpful contribution for any other external controllers that may want to structure their NB API in a similar way (such that they don't have to write a new plugin). Hope that clarifies our thinking in following this naming convention."}, {'account_id': 490, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

It will be nice if all the references to Proxy Plugin were change to Bigswitch, everything else looks good to me!'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

The code looks good for me.

My question is about the name of the plugin. I would like to know opinions from other reviewers.

So far each external controller (OpenFlow controller in many case) has its own northband APIs called from Quantum, and there seems to be no general APIs. They are very similar in many point but they are different each other. Considering this situation, the name of the plugin seems to be general. (There may be a chance to standarlize the APIs in the future.)

/FYI/ NEC plugin also has a similar generic API definition: https://github.com/trema/apps/wiki/Sliceable-Network-Management-API.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Minor issues are inline.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: (1 inline comment)

Hi,
Other files in the project have license in the __init__ files. It should be good to add them for consistency.
I have a minor nit in the README.
I am still going over the plugin code. 
Can you please clarify why there is the notion of attachment? Is this related to Quantum, if so then this seems to V1.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(16 inline comments)

Hi,
Just a few minor issues.
Thanks
Gary"}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

(1 inline comment)

All of the comments that I had previously written have been addressed.
I have not tested the code but in general it looks good.
Thanks
Gary'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-14 07:24:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

commit_message:
RESTProxy Plugin for Floodlight and BigSwitch

blueprint restproxy-plugin

Implements blueprint restproxy-plugin.

This Quantum plugin translates Quantum function calls to authenticated
REST requests to a set of redundant external network controllers.

Change-Id: Idbde6a7403c459503e8e0ee8b25ddaa8af5be36e

commit_message:
plugin/ryu: update for ryu update

blueprint ryu-plugin-update-for-ryu
Now ryu has GRE tunnel support, so update ryu plugin to support it.
This implements/simplifies GRE tunneling support for ryu plugin

Change-Id: I158affcb60c9016753dbbbf5f1ad50286af49c23
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

Doesn't seem to solve the problem at hand.  Also needs more testing if it does solve the dd problem."}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-06 13:14:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Is this referring to the kenrel hang?
Is this ubuntu (version) specific?
Do we have a bug # for this?

cp and dd will do essentially the same here. Well apart from dd using O_DIRECT to bypass more kernel logic/buffer to be more efficient in this regard.

There is an additional work-around (though a little bit of a big hammer) to use ionice, as described in the commit message in Ic842d7b83209c41d8ff05075990ed12e6f86283a
Perhaps that might avoid the kernel issue?'}, {'account_id': 1812, 'date': '2012-11-06 13:38:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As mitigation for this issue, I've resent my previous "configurable volume wiping" change I7312678ff5d66156578501483a1b74e2a69e19a0

This should allow one to set the volume_clear=none config option on the test systems at least, to avoid the issue'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-14 06:03:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

[{'created': '2012-11-06 03:00:07.000000000', 'message': 'Replace dd in delete volume with cp

The issue with dd on volume-delete continues to be a problem.
This patch introduces a temporary work-around to try and use
a direct cp from /dev/zero --> /dev/mapper/xxxxx.

This is an attempt at short term resolution, longer term we should
investigate using a dev-mapper zero solution instead.

Change-Id: Ib7aa4f75a99d9150abfaf00021351cd0d74588cf
'}]
commit_message:
Replace dd in delete volume with cp

The issue with dd on volume-delete continues to be a problem.
This patch introduces a temporary work-around to try and use
a direct cp from /dev/zero --> /dev/mapper/xxxxx.

This is an attempt at short term resolution, longer term we should
investigate using a dev-mapper zero solution instead.

Change-Id: Ib7aa4f75a99d9150abfaf00021351cd0d74588cf

subject: implementation of blueprint object-append
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-25 01:22:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-swift-merge/566 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-swift-docs/196 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-swift-pep8/339 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-swift-python26/445 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-swift-python27/446 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/9266 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-27 20:32:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This seems hugely risky for a feature not often requested.

The same functionality can be accomplished client-side with the trade off of complexity client-side, but at least less risk server-side.

1) COPY <container>/<object> Destination: <container>/<uuid>/0

2) PUT <container>/<uuid>/1 with the data to append

3) PUT <container>/<uuid> with x-object-manifest: <container>/<uuid>/

4) COPY <container>/<uuid> Destination: <container>/<object>

5) DELETE <container>/<uuid>

6) DELETE <container>/<uuid>/1

7) DELETE <container>/<uuid>/0

Admittedly this is a lot more work for the client, but so much safer for the server and data. I'd much rather see the risk put into client language bindings."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-08-27 21:24:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I think this feature is not requested because people think it's impossible to do in Swift with all the object immutability.
The idea in server-side append is that you can read an old revision at any time and new revisions can be appended constantly, one after another.
And then comes the performance impact.
If the data size before append is N and append size is M, then the total data shipping between nodes is: 3*N + 3*M + 3*(N+M) = 6*(N+M)
And I get 3*M with server-side append."}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-08-27 21:40:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

All true and understood. I'm going to keep my -1 opinion, but obviously I can be outvoted."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-08-29 21:20:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-08-29 21:31:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Second iteration, risk was reduced by safeguarding append code to execute only when user explicitly requests the append feature (by setting up some new headers in requests).
Now the critical path has less than 10 loc changed/added.
Changes in critical path logic are contained within get_object_size() only.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-08-29 21:34:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

"}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:11:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:11:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

PEP8 ... fixed.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:21:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

This will also need some documentation as well.  Probably something like a top-level document analogous to the ones for Large Object Support,  Object Versioning, Container to Container Synchronization, and Expiring Object Support.

There may be places in other docs (deployment or admin's guide) which might warrant mention of object append, but I haven't looked in detail."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:28:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

I seem to reliably get this failure in the functional tests:

 ======================================================================
 ERROR: test_append (test.functionalnosetests.test_object.TestObject)
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "/home/swiftstack/swift/test/functionalnosetests/test_object.py", line 579, in test_append
     resp = retry(append)
   File "/home/swiftstack/swift/test/functionalnosetests/swift_testing.py", line 118, in retry
     raise Exception('No result after %s retries.' % retries)
 Exception: No result after 5 retries.

I'm using an SAIO setup with Python 2.7 on Oneiric in VirtualBox.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:37:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(1 inline comment)

Simple rebase merge bug inline."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:42:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Yes, that one slipped through second rebase. Will ifx it now.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:43:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:47:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

It looks like lines 404-419 in swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py still did not have unit test coverage and that's where the aforementioned merge bug lived.

After fixing that bug, I retried my POST to an existing object with

 X-Append-To: 0

and got a 202 Accepted (http://www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec10.html#sec10.2.3).  Is there some asynchronous part to an object append?  I would have expected a 200 and for the append to have been fully completed.  OTOH, I just tried a metadata setting POST with just

 X-Object-Meta-Foo: bar

and also got a 202 Accepted, so I guess that's just what Swift has always done?  If that's not a change in behavior, I don't care too much."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:49:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

swift/proxy/controllers/obj.py lines 404-418 (where that bug was) still not unit tested."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 18:55:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Hrm... do you know if COPY of an appended-to object works?  My config is probably using the default behavior of POST-as-COPY, and my POST with

 X-Object-Meta-Foo: bar

probably copied my appended-to object "under the hood".  Now, when I try to retrieve revision 0, I get all 133 bytes (I PUT a 100 byte file with no append-related headers, then appended another 33 bytes with a POST with "X-Append-To: 0"), and when I try to retrieve revision 1, I get a 404.

Can you test and confirm the actual and expected behavior of COPY on objects which have been appended to (and thus have different revisions)?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-28 19:05:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-swift-merge/1059 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-swift-docs/685 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-swift-pep8/828 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-swift-python26/933 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-swift-python27/935 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/6/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15846 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 19:06:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

COPY of an appended object copies the whole object and removes revisions.
This is an expected behavior, because I don't see a point in saving the append history it's not a replacement for versioning.
Although I see you point in case of POST requests...
I'll think what I can do here.

Regarding proxy tests: didn't check them yet, therefore no full coverage, will add them ASAP."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 19:41:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

OTOH, you could just document that if the proxy server's object_post_as_copy config variable is "true", then you get this behavior with appended-to files.

IIRC, object_post_as_copy owes its (inefficient) existence to the fact that it's the only way to change Content-Type with a POST... or something like that.

Someone else may have a stronger opinion on the behavior of an appended file in the face of a non-appending POST with object_post_as_copy = true... but I'm fine with just documenting what it actually does.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:03:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Would it be useful to include a response header for appended-to objects which indicates the number of stored revisions?

Obviously, you could keep track of the revision count outside of Swift, but it seems odd to have to get the X-Append-To numer exactly right for POSTs, yet there's no way to query for what that is, assuming you haven't been keeping track."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:17:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

There is a magic '-1' revision for that.
I.e. HEAD with 'x-revision = -1' should yield you a latest revision number. In the same spirit 'x-append-to = -1' will append to the latest revision.
Revisions were designed as a consistency plan: i.e. you keep track on client and then send append requests. If there is loss of sync between client and server you will get error as soon as possible and won't overwrite already existing data."}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:28:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (2 inline comments)

Ah, I was just about to ask about negative revisions.  I was sending in "-8", "-2", and the like and observing that I got back the latest revision (I hadn't noticed that I started getting back the X-Revision header in the response, but it is as you said it would be).  So apparently, any negative X-Revision header will yield the X-Revision header in the response and the full object Content-Length (and body if it was a GET).

The magic-ness of negative numbers for X-Revision and X-Append-To should *definitely* be documented :).

Also, please see inline comments for a couple requests.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:36:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Stay tuned for documentation, I will definitely add it.
Question inline.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:48:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: (1 inline comment)

Reply inline.

Also, it looks like this patch may be the first time anyone other than the initial (and only) object PUT writes out metadata stored in an xattr.  That could be a significant change in behavior... I vaguely remember someone (you?) filing a bug or question in launchpad about what happens when xattr metadata size shrinks.  Someone (gholt?) replied that it's irrelevant because Swift only ever writes xattr metadata once.  This would change that, and make that question valid again, right?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 20:58:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

Here's the bug I was thinking of (it wasn't you): https://bugs.launchpad.net/swift/+bug/1065584"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-28 21:00:37.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

...but in this patch's cae, the object's xattr metadata is never shrunk... it's the original size from the PUT, then it might get X-Revision: 0 added, then it might just get an incremented value for X-Revision.  So I don't think that "stranded segment" issue applies here.

Thoughts?'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 21:09:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

Yes you're correct, I never shrink "system" metadata anyway.
And "user" metadata gets appended to a different file which is indeed overwritten with each POST.
There is also no problem with shrinking of "append" metadata as it obviously never shrinks by design.

But there is some sneaky bug that I've fixed in my patch set: the tests do not use read_metadata() function and just try to read only the first key, if the revision is there, the data in the first key could be not sufficient anymore.
That's why I've changed all tests to use correct functions.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 21:13:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

P.S. I can answer why the metadata keys are only 254 bytes: XFS stores 256 byte xattr keys in inode itself and not in the extent space. It greatly improves xattr read/write speed.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 22:08:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-28 22:09:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

Added needed unit tests for proxy branches.
And other fixes from the previous patch set.
Documentation will follow.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-28 22:27:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/7/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15847 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-29 00:50:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-29 00:52:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Docs added. Let's roll."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-29 01:23:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-swift-merge/1061 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-swift-docs/687 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-swift-pep8/830 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-swift-python26/935 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-swift-python27/937 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/8/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/15851 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1216, 'date': '2012-10-29 15:49:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I hadn't looked at this in a while since I'm kind of not the target audience; but the whole revisions thing seems confusing with the existing versions stuff and also seems unnecessary. Why can't you achieve the same goals with just etags and if-matches?

I'm also curious how replication conflicts are resolved. Perhaps I'm just missing it, but if each node has a different revision and nothing more ever comes from the client, how is this resolved?"}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-29 15:53:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (4 inline comments)

A few doc notes inline.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-29 17:40:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

Hmm, If-Match header looks fit for the job. The only problem I see here: getting specific file revision will be slow, but that's not the main use case."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-29 17:48:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: (3 inline comments)

Commented on inline ones.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-30 14:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-30 14:59:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-swift-merge/1073 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-swift-docs/699 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-swift-pep8/842 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-swift-python26/947 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-swift-python27/949 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/11969/9/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/16041 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-30 15:14:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

To gholt: I've added "Replication" to the doc that explains briefly the replication behavior. Essentially the behavior is exactly the same as in case of subsequent PUTs on the same object several times. I.e. the newest object wins, regardless of anything that happened in between.
I've also checked my design notes from 4 month ago when I first started with append to see why I've overlooked If-Match, and sadly it was dropped due to not adding much value. I.e. POST with If-Match cannot be used verbatim as we will need some indication that this is an append operation.
And when getting object If-Match will only complicate lookup as the client now has no means to check the history of a file without actually tracking that history locally (including the trick for saving md5 state between runs).

To Darrel: document was updated with more info.'}, {'account_id': 2828, 'date': '2012-10-30 16:00:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

I'm concerned that it seems to modify data files in place with no type of transactional semantics.

And generally I'm concerned that it makes the obj server considerably more complex for a feature that I don't know who really wants it for what?"}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-30 16:16:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Transactions are not needed when appending to file.
The worst case is that you will read data up until previous version, and that's it. Append cannot partially succeed, essentially "file size" is the only "journal" parameter that's needed and it's always written after append is finished.
This feature is needed for any application that uses append-only data files. I have two usable examples: HBASE data files and ZFS filesystem images.'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-30 16:38:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9:

Can you flesh out the commit message a little, but definitely add "DocImpact" somewhere per this request to the mailing list: http://www.mail-archive.com/openstack@lists.launchpad.net/msg17700.html'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-30 21:57:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-10-30 21:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-30 22:17:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Works for me

commit_message:
implementation of blueprint object-append

DocImpact: added append feature overview
Changes:
- add new resumable md5 implementation to object server
- added POST with X-Append-To handling to obejct server
- added GET/HEAD with X-Revision handling to object server
- added X-Append-To and X-Revision handling to proxy object controller
- changed DiskFile to read file size data from metadata only
- added unit tests and functional tests

Change-Id: I7114a0a7ec21d9677c670cae242b945915e71524

commit_message:
Always filter by tenant_id in stack_get_by_name.

This means that all calls to stack_get_by_name need to provide a context.

Without this change, 2 tenants cannot create stacks with the same name.

Change-Id: I98c35a5d51c5c7d66e0b8a0fddc04f221d1d6ab7

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 03:57:09.000000000', 'message': "Removes fixed_ip_get_network

Removes fixed_ip_get_network since it doesn't actually work anymore
(at some point in the past the network must have been stored along
with the network_uuid but this is no longer the case) and nothing
else uses it anyway.

Also cleans up fake db test model to remove the fake_fixed_ip_get_network
and underlying network reference which makes it closer in sync
to what is actually implemented now

Change-Id: I01dc0f88a8bc7cfef01c4e7f328bcdba75a8e0bc
"}]
commit_message:
Removes fixed_ip_get_network

Removes fixed_ip_get_network since it doesn't actually work anymore
(at some point in the past the network must have been stored along
with the network_uuid but this is no longer the case) and nothing
else uses it anyway.

Also cleans up fake db test model to remove the fake_fixed_ip_get_network
and underlying network reference which makes it closer in sync
to what is actually implemented now

Change-Id: I01dc0f88a8bc7cfef01c4e7f328bcdba75a8e0bc

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 18:58:13.000000000', 'message': "Code cleanup: remove ImageAddResult class.

Remove the unused ImageAddResult class and fix the misleading comments
implying that it was used.

I did rewrite the code to use ImageAddResult, but I don't think it was
an improvement.  I think tuples are perfect for simply grouping things
to return them together.

Change-Id: Iabf0022b1a95e25a8111dbc38f7be4be3f5e6f59
"}]
commit_message:
Code cleanup: remove ImageAddResult class.

Remove the unused ImageAddResult class and fix the misleading comments
implying that it was used.

I did rewrite the code to use ImageAddResult, but I don't think it was
an improvement.  I think tuples are perfect for simply grouping things
to return them together.

Change-Id: Iabf0022b1a95e25a8111dbc38f7be4be3f5e6f59

commit_message:
Align pip-requires versions with nova

This should also make the unit tests run again by preventing
SqlAlchemy 8 from being used

Change-Id: I6fa92540dc3369b85d135232b10701937071cbd6

Yes, https://review.openstack.org/15952 may well provide the genesis of the best long-term approach, but there are still issues to be worked out as to how this fits in with the evolving internal nova interactions, still in a state of flux due to the ongoing no-db-compute re-architecting.

So this current patch is purely intended as a pragmatic way of addressing a breakage in trunk, without prejudicing any future more strategic changes in the nova interaction model.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 16:40:46.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid TypeError when loading libvirt.LibvirtDriver

Fixes bug 1078304

The libvirt.LibvirtDriver.__init__() signature has changed since:

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/081b652c

to take a new virtapi parameter. This is not required by any
ceilometer usage of the driver, however the absence of a
corresponding argument causes importutils.import_object_ns()
to fail with TypeError.

For testing the nova fake.FakeVirtAPI still uses the old
signature, hence we try both.

Change-Id: I05a9728ceb435a72f5fa8a648cd70b079126396e
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid TypeError when loading libvirt.LibvirtDriver

Fixes bug 1078304

The libvirt.LibvirtDriver.__init__() signature has changed since:

  https://github.com/openstack/nova/commit/081b652c

to take a new virtapi parameter. This is not required by any
ceilometer usage of the driver, however the absence of a
corresponding argument causes importutils.import_object_ns()
to fail with TypeError.

For testing the nova fake.FakeVirtAPI still uses the old
signature, hence we try both.

Change-Id: I05a9728ceb435a72f5fa8a648cd70b079126396e

commit_message:
Update vol mount smoketest to wait for volume.

Updates the test_003_can_mount_volume smoke test so that it
waits for the volume to show up in /proc/partitions for up
to 60 seconds before proceeding. This eliminates the need for
a hard coded sleep value which can cause intermittent test failures.

Change-Id: Ibdc56a00e141211e40068c22fc268efeba6affff

commit_message:
Show gw_port and interfaces information with router-show command.

Bug #1069782

We get router's interface information after geting router. And then
we use dump it with pretty format.

This patch also formats the list dump with pretty json dumping.

The result can be seen at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Ctago2g2OAH8ZPCdjkfFfF7LsVzgQeqw6MVmnLI0avg/edit
Change-Id: I119d399b8a39b808d4635183995256b4d5f4de98

middleware installed.

commit_message:
Fixes is_image_visible to not use deleted key

The 'is_image_visible' method is looking for deleted members while
they are already being filtered in the query. Registry while validating
all the members gets a KeyError as the key deleted does not exist.

Fixes Bug: 1077106

Change-Id: Ia53b6be3b2f740357df86e6c7a6a257a990c3aab

subject: Determine flavor type from the public nova API.
messages:
[{'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 14:33:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/1/check/gate-ceilometer-merge/700 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/1/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/695 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/1/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/695 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/1/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/697 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 1669, 'date': '2012-11-13 15:42:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I admit that this is a change from how it was done previously, but I see only downside to come back to this, especially this way:

1. Caching can lead to mistakes if change happens to the flavor list while ceilomter is running;
2. Using flavor id allow to differentiate changes done on flavor themselves even if a flavor keeps a name. So we have more information."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-13 15:45:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-13 16:12:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 16:17:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/2/check/gate-ceilometer-merge/704 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/2/check/gate-ceilometer-pep8/699 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python26/699 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15977/2/check/gate-ceilometer-python27/701 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-13 16:23:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@jd_

Are you suggesting that we switch from say metering instance:m1.small to instance:2?

Presumably the potential for problems only occurs when an admin deletes a flavor then recreates it with the same name but chooses a different ID *and* a different resource configuration (as there is no flavor update operation AFAIK).

However I don't think switching to instance:<flavor-id> is a silver bullet, as the flavor could be recreated with the same ID but a different resource configuration (or even with a different ID and the same resource configuration).

Cheers,
Eoghan"}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2012-11-13 16:35:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Oh, man, this is worse than I thought. The ID of a flavor is only unique among non-deleted flavors and the user controls the ID value when they make the API call to create a new flavor (allowing the caller to reuse an ID). The definition of a flavor, either by name or by ID, may change between the time a meter is collected and it is consumed through the ceilometer API.

The end-user doesn't have access to flavors, though, right? That's something left for the deployer to control?"}, {'account_id': 2284, 'date': '2012-11-13 16:47:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

@dhellmann

> The definition of a flavor, either by name or by ID, may change between the time a meter is collected and it is consumed through the ceilometer API.

Exactly, which is why instance.id is really no better than instance.name.

> The end-user doesn't have access to flavors, though, right? That's something left for the deployer to control?

Well it depends on the RBAC rules defined in the deployed policy.json.

But yes, in the default policy.json, the relevant rule is set to:

  "compute_extension:flavormanage": "rule:admin_api"

which restricts it to administrative users.

Cheers,

commit_message:
Determine flavor type from the public nova API.

Fixes bug 1078298

Previously the flavor name used in the flavor-specific instance meter
was available from the nova DB instance representation.

Now that we retrieve the on-host instances from the public nova
API as opposed to the DB, we need to retrieve and cache the flavor
name separately.

Change-Id: Ifd15eedd34e4128d5f9bdaa9318049e973dac9ed

For the coverage extension having all the backdoor ports available centrally is needed, it'll enable just looping over all the listed backdoor ports and starting up coverage on each service. If multiple configuration files are used I'm not sure how we can go about doing an equivalent action to get all the ports we need to use.

I'm sure that there could be similar use cases in the future that will need to use the backdoor on all the services at once. If adding config options for each service isn't the solution does anyone have any suggestions on another approach that would work?"}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-05 22:08:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think I get why reading this set of options is easy, but reading an option out of multiple files doesn't work.

We're nearing the point where we should just move this to the openstack-dev mailing list."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-05 23:40:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

definitely agree it's probably mailing list time to put everyone's heads together on a good way to deal with this. Part of the equation is figuring out how to run this in a devstack periodic job in the CI system with tempest. Multiple file generation becomes a bit more problematic there."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-06 19:38:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

We set the port to 0 in our testing deployments. As a result, a random port is allocated to listen on for each service.

This pushes the complexity from configuration to figuring out which port belongs to which process. I've done that mostly by using 'netstat -nltp' by hand.

I wonder how difficult it would be to script that..."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-08 04:46:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

+1 to port 0 and figuring out where they end up.'}, {'account_id': 5196, 'date': '2012-11-13 21:32:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Abandoned

Another approach to solve this problem:
https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15679/'}]

commit_message:
Change configuration for eventlet_backdoor to be per service.

Each nova service requires a different port for the backdoor server.
This changes the configuration option to be per service. Now each
service that will start a backdoor server will have it's own port
set in nova.conf.

The backdoor_port option is removed and these options are added:

backdoor_port_api
backdoor_port_cpu
backdoor_port_cert
backdoor_port_cauth
backdoor_port_cons
backdoor_port_net
backdoor_port_sch
backdoor_port_meta
backdoor_port_ec2

Change-Id: Id68d22c7277b2ce748611aa583c787d4c762f614
Signed-off-by: Matthew Treinish <treinish@linux.vnet.ibm.com>

commit_message:
Added a check for volume service in quota functions

When displaying the quotas, we have to check if
volume service is present in the service catalog.
If not - then to remove the volume quotas from
the result object.

Fixes bug 1075319

Change-Id: Icd049a5b147cac039add1570a166d775fd0d6ec4

subject: When editing an image, correctly set the 'is_public' checkbox.
messages:
[{'account_id': 4978, 'date': '2012-11-12 18:56:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This (simple enough, one line of actual change) patch has been accepted into the master branch, the only difference here being the path names in the test.

From a comment I made on the bug report with regard to the backport potential:

This fix is heavily dependent on the glance client version, as indicated by Gabriel Hurley in his review. The glance client change [0] happened between the 0.4.0 and 0.4.1 version tag (August).

If this fix is applied to a codebase that relies on the older client library version, the checkbox will instead always reset to "True" for is_public, which may have more serious privacy implications as users could accidentally turn private images public...

At the moment Horizon's tools/pip-requires only lists python-glanceclient<2 with no minimum version. However both Ubuntu and Fedora seem to ship 0.5.1 only, and if we assume users tracking folsom would also use a recent version of the glance client, then it is probably safe enough to consider it for a backport.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/python-glanceclient/commit/8f0d5c4f2cea6e5dae827b5f728c54dab4a4386b'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-11-12 19:05:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Add DB query to get in-progress migrations.

Adds DB query to get in-progress migrations.  This will be needed
by resource tracker to get more accurate usage values around inbound
and outbound resizes.

bug 1065267

Change-Id: Ib111002c70aa16e404c6e2c3fcb4ad234177ce91

commit_message:
Support name or id for stack operations.

Includes the followig changes:
- move format_parameters to common/utils.py
- Separate columns for ID and Name in list pretty print table
- Accept ID or Name for all operations
- Fix from radaz to correctly respond to redirects

Change-Id: Ie2d7c03f682d43454cb1348188fa56ad001e1bb1

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 19:49:09.000000000', 'message': 'Pass username and password as well as token.

This matches the behaviour of heat-cfn.
One day Heat will support doing all operations with only a token. Today is not that day.
Also add a --token-only option to suppress sending username/password.

Change-Id: Ib439d770e90d381ffc83babf7fca85c9f1e32e64
'}]
commit_message:
Pass username and password as well as token.

This matches the behaviour of heat-cfn.
One day Heat will support doing all operations with only a token. Today is not that day.
Also add a --token-only option to suppress sending username/password.

Change-Id: Ib439d770e90d381ffc83babf7fca85c9f1e32e64

commit_message:
Embed extension data in the headers

The token verification response can have all sorts of extension
data that the auth_token.py middleware doesn't include in any
headers.  This adds optional headers which will contain any
extension data that was present in the verification response.

Change-Id: Icf5b540958c933f9e7961d9d7a867fb62b1d141d

commit_message:
Removes dead code related of nova-volume Xen SM

This code is not required, now nova-volume has been removed.
It is being re-implemented in a new way inside Cinder.

The volume attach/detach code is still useful for Cinder,
and is not being removed

Fixes LP Bug #1076977

Change-Id: I7a51454d72f0a8605d26a5ef57cc4be9999e1df9

bug #?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:40:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-merge/450 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-docs/301 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-pep8/445 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-python26/377 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-python-keystoneclient-python27/379 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15970/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/18283 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:02:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I like the idea and the code path, but this logic would be much better suited to being encapsulated in the manage_url() @property of AccessInfo, and it needs a test as well to illustrate and verify it's functionality."}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:52:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well, I see what you mean... but I went for the less intrusive change.

I don't really like some properties of AccessInfo. For example: if a property returns a tuple, it never should return None. I would expect an empty tuple instead.

But even if that was the case, blindly accessing the first element of management_url tuple is wrong because it assumes that if scoped is True, there will an adminURL (thus management_url won't be None), and apparently that's not always the case.

I don't want to do a bigger change without a thumbs up of you guys.

Summing up:

 - AccessInfo properties returning a tuple, should always return a tuple (an empty one it's OK).
 - In keystoneclient.v2_0.client.Client.authenticate doing self.management_url = self.auth_ref.management_url[0] is wrong. It should check that self.auth_ref.management_url has at least one item.

Thanks your your support."}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-13 17:59:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I'd be game to do that - I struggled with returning None vs. a tuple vs. throwing an exception if values didn't exist. For python truthiness, an empty tuple is False, so there's a reasonable path to checking. 

I started changing the other endpoints to always returning a list, and I think we'll need to do something "special" with endpoint regardless - not assuming that we can always pull it from a token since RAX doesn't include it, but it might have been provided in otherwise (i.e. through client or --endpoint override)'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-11-13 18:05:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

OK, all right!

I'm going to abandon this change (it's what I'm using locally to workaround the problem, so I'm not in a hurry to have it "fixed").

Let me know if you want me to work on the stuff I commented before.'}, {'account_id': 894, 'date': '2012-11-13 18:07:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

AccessInfo needs to be changed to be more consistent in some properties (returning empty tuples instead of None).

Then management_url can be tested to have at least one item before using it.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 13:20:03.000000000', 'message': "adminURL may not be available.

If there's no adminURL endpoint in the serviceCatalog (ie. in a objtect-store,
in Rackspace identity service there's onlu publicURL and internalURL), unconditionally
accessing the first element of management_url property of AccesInfo may raise:

  Authorization Failed: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__getitem__'

This change verifies that management_url is a tuple, otherwise management_url will be None.

Change-Id: Ib17987acfbad59165de62ae963857519b867c96d
"}]
commit_message:
adminURL may not be available.

If there's no adminURL endpoint in the serviceCatalog (ie. in a objtect-store,
in Rackspace identity service there's onlu publicURL and internalURL), unconditionally
accessing the first element of management_url property of AccesInfo may raise:

  Authorization Failed: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__getitem__'

This change verifies that management_url is a tuple, otherwise management_url will be None.

Change-Id: Ib17987acfbad59165de62ae963857519b867c96d

commit_message:
Add auth-token code to keystoneclient, along with supporting files

This step in the process duplicates the auth-token code to keystoneclient but,
for the moment, leaves a copy in its origional location in keystone.
Testing for auth-token is also copied across, as is the cms support file.

Although no other project will yet pick up the code here in the client, since
the paste.ini files haev not yet been updated, it would work if anyone
did reference it.

Once the client code is in, the next step is to update all the other
project paste files, and then finally retire the code from keystone.

Change-Id: I88853a373d406020d54b61cba5a5e887380e3b3e

commit_message:
patch utils.HASH_PATH_SUFFIX in proxy unittests

Most of the test files set the HASH_PATH_SUFFIX so you can run the test
file stand alone.  This change made it easier for me to run specific
proxy tests separately.

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 22:11:36.000000000', 'message': 'Try hard shutdown if clean fails on resize down

In the xenapi driver, a clean shutdown is attempted before a resize
down.  If the Xenapi raises an exception it is logged and ignored and
the resize will fail later in the process.  This adds a hard shutdown
attempt if the clean shutdown fails.

Change-Id: I458931a19dd2375ad7142d60cb8b6ed274de9483
'}, {'created': '2012-11-13 16:30:43.000000000', 'message': 'Try hard shutdown if clean fails on resize down

commit_message:
Try hard shutdown if clean fails on resize down

In the xenapi driver, a clean shutdown is attempted before a resize
down.  If the Xenapi raises an exception it is logged and ignored and
the resize will fail later in the process.  This adds a hard shutdown
attempt if the clean shutdown fails.

Change-Id: I458931a19dd2375ad7142d60cb8b6ed274de9483

Patchset amends commit message and updates the sample glance-api.conf file.

commit_message:
fix deletion of LVM backed instances

    The enumeration of the logical volumes was incorrect,
    thus causing the deletion of instances booted from them,
    to fail.

    Fixes bug: 1078085
    Change-Id: Ib899754002cea28f310b042e5d4a7f89416e031e
    Cherry-picked: 3c9e48d1119b77428346680c2a009c44ff9bf2ce

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15845/1/gate/gate-heat-merge/1084 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15845/1/gate/gate-heat-pep8/1084 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15845/1/gate/gate-heat-python26/1084 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15845/1/gate/gate-heat-python27/1084 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 4571, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

Just one question inline.'}, {'account_id': 4715, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: (1 inline comment)

The premise of this is not really correct.

1) We are doing a Query.get() to fetch the object by its primary key, so there is actually no query being run on the database either time.

2) SQLAlchemy does cache objects per session in the identity map, so the object does not need to be fetched from the database again. Documentation here: http://docs.sqlalchemy.org/en/latest/orm/query.html#sqlalchemy.orm.query.Query.get


However, what we _do_ have is a long-standing problem of doing every database operation in a separate session (meaning that in this case, we do fetch it twice). We need to fix *that*; IMO this change is just adding complexity without addressing the real issue.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-13 13:42:52.000000000', 'message': "Pass a Stack entity to Stack.load().

Every call to Stack.load (except one) is loading models.Stack then passing just
the ID to Stack.load, which then loads models.Stack again.

As far as I can tell, SQLAlchemy doesn't have a 2nd level cache, so this results
in the db being queried twice.

This change makes it possibe to pass a stack *or* an ID to Stack.load, and
converts all calls to pass in a stack if it is available.

Change-Id: I501ebd403a241cc3b4a5c1e3070137cfc360bbda
"}]
commit_message:
Pass a Stack entity to Stack.load().

Every call to Stack.load (except one) is loading models.Stack then passing just
the ID to Stack.load, which then loads models.Stack again.

As far as I can tell, SQLAlchemy doesn't have a 2nd level cache, so this results
in the db being queried twice.

This change makes it possibe to pass a stack *or* an ID to Stack.load, and
converts all calls to pass in a stack if it is available.

Change-Id: I501ebd403a241cc3b4a5c1e3070137cfc360bbda

commit_message:
Report correct return value from pep8 check

Remove the '|| true' appended to the pep8 command to allow
the non-zero status to be returned properly.

Fix bug 1073380.

Change-Id: I1e212a9d596eb448ee7f6ac40106a05650b70473

commit_message:
let image-list --name show all matching images

With this patch using image-list --name will show all matching images.
For example if you search for "foobar" all images containing "foobar"
in the name will be displayed.

fixes bug 917692

Change-Id: I8087ace0c3e7998ce9b99247bee985bc37a84bcd

commit_message:
plugin/ryu: add tunnel support

blueprint ryu-tunnel-support
This patch adds tunneling support to Ryu plugin.
Ryu supports gre tunneling which requires quantum ryu plugin to manage
key assignment.

Change-Id: I9f8db0913941c3da13045170e1557d333f0c68e2
Signed-off-by: Isaku Yamahata <yamahata@valinux.co.jp>

Can you clean up the extra seemingly-unrelated whitespace damage you did in patch set 4? Unless there's some reason for the changes..."}, {'account_id': 5371, 'date': '2012-10-22 14:14:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

@Dan Smith: I was getting PEP8 warnings for those hanging indents and figured I would take care of them while changing some of the LOG.error's to LOG.exception's.
However, I'm running pep8 1.3.3 which seems to have a lot more checks."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-22 18:42:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me, but someone else must approve

Okay, fair enough. I think that the version of pep8 in use in the CI stack right now is tolerant of them, but there was mention of revving it again at the summit.'}, {'account_id': 1849, 'date': '2012-10-22 18:53:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I don't think this patch should cover pep8 1.3.3 fixes, until we are sure we want to enforce those specific pep8 1.3.3. warnings.  We currently do not enforce all pep8 1.2 warnings, and may not want to enforce all pep8 1.3.3. warnings.

In the past we have rejected patches that do not fix pep8 problems in the current version of pep8 (unless we are about to switch) https://review.openstack.org/#/c/12391/"}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-10-22 18:59:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

I'm certainly in favor of separating out pep8 changes from functional ones. Separate patches would be ideal, IMHO.

However, in the release meeting on Thursday, it sounded like a rev to pep8 was likely early in the grizzly cycle (i.e. nowish) and then sticking to that until H, which is why I figured it's reasonable to just tuck them in here anyway :)"}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-10-30 06:03:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
powervm: failed spawn should raise exception

fixes bug #1065295

On a failed spawn instance, we should run our cleanup on
the host and then re-raise the exception to inform
ComputeManager of a failure

Change-Id: Ia9ce8360117e94d10d53278d4c9a16931dea70f2

commit_message:
Mv copyright holder of docs: OpenStack Foundation

fixes bug 1078042

We have been advised by the board that the copyright holder of the
docs should now be OpenStack Foundation, which replaces OpenStack
LLC

Change-Id: I105073b8837093e499a094496eff8be74bf2435d

commit_message:
Remove custom test assertions.

Now that we testtools, We can use stock testtools assert methods
instead of defining our own. As part of removing them, we add Matcher
classes to use in the testtools.assertThat method. testtools matchers can
be arbitrarily combined and chained, so give more flexibility than plain
asserts

Related to blueprint grizzly-testtools.

Change-Id: I26d1dbac8dc3c322eb55c96c48330c0e38636107

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-01 15:18:02.000000000', 'message': "Add REST API support for list/enable/disable nova services

Implements one workitem of blueprint apis-for-nova-manage

This adds an extension that provides REST API for list/enable/
disable nova service. The interface ia accessed via

GET /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/enable
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/disable

And the command:nova host-describe have implemented the functionality
of nova-manage service describe_resource. So we needn't add a REST
API for it.

Change-Id: I030a7e00b878d7931456e7e323db37b7c47fce48

commit_message:
Add REST API support for list/enable/disable nova services

Implements one workitem of blueprint apis-for-nova-manage

This adds an extension that provides REST API for list/enable/
disable nova service. The interface ia accessed via

GET /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/enable
PUT /v2/{tenant_id}/os-services/disable

And the command:nova host-describe have implemented the functionality
of nova-manage service describe_resource. So we needn't add a REST
API for it.

DocImpact
Change-Id: I030a7e00b878d7931456e7e323db37b7c47fce48

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 19:55:51.000000000', 'message': 'threadgroup : greethread.cancel() should be kill()

According to the eventlet documentation, cancel() will only stop a thread if
called before the thread starts running, which is not what we want in this
context - calling kill() here ensures that a currently running thread is
actually stopped, which does not happen with the current cancel() call
See : http://eventlet.net/doc/modules/greenthread.html

Change-Id: I89c5bb3eb21e656bd865d5082779cf9ab83ad326
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
threadgroup : greethread.cancel() should be kill()

According to the eventlet documentation, cancel() will only stop a thread if
called before the thread starts running, which is not what we want in this
context - calling kill() here ensures that a currently running thread is
actually stopped, which does not happen with the current cancel() call
See : http://eventlet.net/doc/modules/greenthread.html

Change-Id: I89c5bb3eb21e656bd865d5082779cf9ab83ad326
Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'message': 'Fix QPID reconnect issues

The problem results from the eventlet monkey patching and the way in
which qpid performs the session reconnection. The solution is to have
the qpid reconnection disbaled and the common rpc code performing the
reconnection.

The time waiting between reconnections will be a multiple
of 2 starting at 1 and a maximum of 60 seconds.

This works around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I3c53211d23e4e68ed73046cb3c637662ab73b339

commit_message:
Fix QPID reconnect issues

The problem results from the eventlet monkey patching and the way in
which qpid performs the session reconnection. The solution is to have
the qpid reconnection disbaled and the common rpc code performing the
reconnection.

The time waiting between reconnections will be a multiple
of 2 starting at 1 and a maximum of 60 seconds.

This works around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I3c53211d23e4e68ed73046cb3c637662ab73b339

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-06 02:03:16.000000000', 'message': 'Two Tests Now Pass as Root

fixes Bug #1062307

The two tests indicated in the bug report fail as root. These tests
specifically address the behavior when certain commands are run as
non-root. Root overrides the permissions that were changed in the
two tests and so they were failing. These tests are unnecessary
when run as root.

Change-Id: I9beb2885d2050bfad7bec85d6d8dcb595fdcc04d
'}]
commit_message:
Two Tests Now Pass as Root

fixes Bug #1062307

The two tests indicated in the bug report fail as root. These tests
specifically address the behavior when certain commands are run as
non-root. Root overrides the permissions that were changed in the
two tests and so they were failing. These tests are unnecessary
when run as root.

Change-Id: I9beb2885d2050bfad7bec85d6d8dcb595fdcc04d

commit_message:
xenapi: Introduce volume manager, and drivers

Relates to blueprint xenapi-volume-drivers

Introducing volume manager, and volume driver.
volume driver is responsible for creating a vdi by a given
connection_data.
volume manager connects the created vdi to an instance, on failure, asks
the driver to rollback. This change moves the attach code from vmops,
and adds some tests as well.

Change-Id: Iefcde2632b55734b0fc40f4981fab5b97db1a423

commit_message:
make libvirt with Xen more workable

- Xen creates it's own tap devices when using libvirt, unplugging in
  Nova is not necessary

- 'script' should be None for Xen using libvirt with Quantum Linux
  Bridge Agent

- live migration is not working because the libvirt method
  virConnectCompareCPU is not implemented for Xen

Change-Id: Ibb937f75763cb83691a056ca41e244e171499fbb

'}]
commit_message:
Make xenapi shutdown mode explicit

Split shutdown_vm in the xenapi utilities into two methods with clear
names defining their behavior rather than relying on a default argument
being passed in.

This makes something like the following more clear than it would be
currently:

if not clean_shutdown_vm():
    hard_shutdown_vm()

Change-Id: Ia7079197c8b8726c7e2ddc508b301162a02baa1b

[{'created': '2012-11-12 17:46:38.000000000', 'message': "Move libvirt specific cgroups setup code out of nova.virt.disk.api

The nova.virt.disk.api module contains code that is generically
reusable for any hypervisor. Thus the 'bind' method should not
contain Libvirt LXC specific cgroups code

Change-Id: I919b74c2c4af8ba05b1005ea93d2164be69612ba
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Move libvirt specific cgroups setup code out of nova.virt.disk.api

The nova.virt.disk.api module contains code that is generically
reusable for any hypervisor. Thus the 'bind' method should not
contain Libvirt LXC specific cgroups code

Change-Id: I919b74c2c4af8ba05b1005ea93d2164be69612ba
Signed-off-by: Daniel P. Berrange <berrange@redhat.com>

[{'created': '2012-11-06 19:09:56.000000000', 'message': "Use base image for rescue instance.

commit_message:
Use base image for rescue instance.

Rescue mode was using the instance's current image when building the
rescue VM. This is a problem because that image may be broken, hence the
need for the rescue operation.

Rescue should use the 'base' image instead.

Fixes bug 1075701

Change-Id: Ie3e65cc75c4710f7b6391d5111cb096755e600d4

commit_message:
Clean up __main__ execution from two tests for consistency

We can run individual tests with nose,
and most of the tests in the tree don't include __main__ sections.
This patch cleans up the two oddball cases for consistency.

Change-Id: I78860e1b651982279944c7cf2caff251b9feee90

commit_message:
Modify identify_stack to check for uuid.

If the passed name matches a uuid then lookup by uuid instead of name.

Change-Id: I2058616ce0191aab4d364b652f1b20d072f6b258

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 17:57:16.000000000', 'message': 'Restore keystone --token/--endpoint (bug 1077672)

Commit 2ca3a6 [1] included some changes that were specific to grizzly a bit
too soon. This change reverts --os-token to --token and --os-endpoint to
--endpoint as seen in keystoneclient during the folsom timeframe.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/2ca3a64c0cf009b649a8

Change-Id: Ide33fb1d4acba46a8d444ab9d4d3d604dc916763
'}]
commit_message:
Restore keystone --token/--endpoint (bug 1077672)

Commit 2ca3a6 [1] included some changes that were specific to grizzly a bit
too soon. This change reverts --os-token to --token and --os-endpoint to
--endpoint as seen in keystoneclient during the folsom timeframe.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/2ca3a64c0cf009b649a8

Change-Id: Ide33fb1d4acba46a8d444ab9d4d3d604dc916763

[{'created': '2012-11-12 20:37:51.000000000', 'message': "Fix a bug in XenAPISession's use of virtapi

When the aggregate_get_by_host() call was moved to virtapi,
the XenAPISession's use of it was changed incorrectly. This
fixes that, and also adds a test that would have caught it.

Change-Id: I13ed36efcb7d285e3a99accb007bb0c263b3179c
"}]
commit_message:
Fix a bug in XenAPISession's use of virtapi

When the aggregate_get_by_host() call was moved to virtapi,
the XenAPISession's use of it was changed incorrectly. This
fixes that, and also adds a test that would have caught it.

Change-Id: I13ed36efcb7d285e3a99accb007bb0c263b3179c

commit_message:
Ban db import from nova/virt

This makes hacking.py complain if someone adds something like:

  from nova import db

into any of the files in nova/virt/* (aside from the fake.py file).
It also removes the rest of the dangling db imports that are no
longer needed.

Yay!

Change-Id: Iba3d53b87e65e33a55f8e5033b5d1d33b28d12f7

[{'created': '2012-11-09 22:02:20.000000000', 'message': 'Prevent infinite respawn of child processes

Rather than looking for an exit code of 2 to prevent child processes
from respawning, we look for any non-zero status.

Fixes bug 1074132.
Fixes bug 1065197.

Change-Id: I74ac13737d8a9b8710a8268eb1d67fbe5e75d491
'}]
commit_message:
Prevent infinite respawn of child processes

Rather than looking for an exit code of 2 to prevent child processes
from respawning, we look for any non-zero status.

Fixes bug 1074132.
Fixes bug 1065197.

Change-Id: I74ac13737d8a9b8710a8268eb1d67fbe5e75d491

commit_message:
Fix getattr usage

Class 'object' has no '__getattr__' member as pylint pointed out.
Use the getattr function.

Change-Id: I38c6075ac477e2fe33870bed64b0e5e986175305

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 20:35:02.000000000', 'message': "heat engine : Don't wait() for killed greenthreads

We don't care about the return value of any killed threads on
delete_stack, and the greenthreads will all raise a GreenletExit
exception after being kill()'d anyway.
Also see related openstack-common fix : https://review.openstack.org/15906

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
heat engine : Don't wait() for killed greenthreads

We don't care about the return value of any killed threads on
delete_stack, and the greenthreads will all raise a GreenletExit
exception after being kill()'d anyway.
Also see related openstack-common fix : https://review.openstack.org/15906

Signed-off-by: Steven Hardy <shardy@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Move agent_build_get_by_triple to VirtAPI

This adds a method to the VirtAPI for fetching information about
the guest agents. It would be nice to avoid having to have this be
passed into the virt driver on spawn (and migrate, and resize),
but I think that asking the compute manager to guess what the virt
driver wants for each of the parameters (or grab them all) is
probably no better.

Related to bp:no-db-virt

Change-Id: I27fb4bd85e6c6bb11e01fb652b199956df88804d

commit_message:
Code cleanup: remove ImageAddResult class.

Remove the unused ImageAddResult class and fix the misleading comments
implying that it was used.

I did rewrite the code to use ImageAddResult, but I don't think it was
an improvement.  I think tuples are perfect for simply grouping things
to return them together.

Change-Id: I24ee01ed979eeb54410444c57b6d059e96ee1230

commit_message:
Avoid unnecessary system_metadata db lookup

The bittorrent code in the xenapi driver added a specific database
query for the instance_system_metadata. This query is unnecessary,
as the system_metadata is available in the instance object itself.
This patch removes the queries and adds the small amount of
format translation required.

Change-Id: If72593289e18d2c45db8e782972eb9051e10d740

commit_message:
Make instance_system_metadata load with instance

Right now, instance['system_metadata'] is demand-loaded at the
first use. This adds the necessary db fu to make it load at
instance_get_*() time.

Change-Id: Id29342fd34fe710b797b23558ef0fde8809231bc

commit_message:
Add some xenapi Bittorrent tests

When the bittorrent support was added to the xenapi driver, no
tests were added. This patch adds a few, specifically around the
use of instance_system_metadata fetches from the database.

Change-Id: I165acd002e35e30c46fc60fc4de1ca6e07bb8845

commit_message:
Move security groups and firewall ops to VirtAPI

This patch moves the following network security-related
methods to VirtAPI:

  security_group_get_by_instance()
  security_group_rule_get_by_security_group()
  provider_fw_rule_get_all()

In order to make this change, the _provider_rules() method
of the FirewallDriver was changed from being a staticmethod
to a regular instance method. All uses of it were in the
context of an actual instance, so I saw no reason to keep
it static, which would have complicated the use of the VirtAPI
methods.

Related to bp:no-db-compute

Change-Id: I260c96b6aa4bbab694b74087f704b6405360b0bf

This patch moves the following virt driver host aggregate
operations to the VirtAPI:

  aggregate_get_by_host()
  aggregate_metadata_get()
  aggregate_metadata_add()
  aggregate_metadata_delete()

In the process, a bug was found in the xenapi/host.py code
that raises an AggregateHostNotFound error in such a way that
a KeyError is generated. This changes that behavior to raise
a NotFound instead, since the former expects you to already
know the aggregate_id, which we do not. This patch extends the
XenAPI host_maintenance_mode test to exercise this error path,
as well as the one where a host is not found within the returned
aggregate.

Related to bp/no-db-compute

Change-Id: I006665bfb27774d2eeb713b79c188ca53f6fb00b

commit_message:
Move host aggregate operations to VirtAPI

This patch moves the following virt driver host aggregate
operations to the VirtAPI:

  aggregate_get_by_host()
  aggregate_metadata_get()
  aggregate_metadata_add()
  aggregate_metadata_delete()

In the process, a bug was found in the xenapi/host.py code
that raises an AggregateHostNotFound error in such a way that
a KeyError is generated. This changes that behavior to raise
a NotFound instead, since the former expects you to already
know the aggregate_id, which we do not. This patch extends the
XenAPI host_maintenance_mode test to exercise this error path,
as well as the one where a host is not found within the returned
aggregate.

Related to bp/no-db-compute

Change-Id: I006665bfb27774d2eeb713b79c188ca53f6fb00b
