[{'created': '2012-11-11 18:15:01.000000000', 'message': 'Update use of nova config to work with folsom

The configuration API for nova changed between folsom and
grizzly. This change uses the folsom API if necessary,
allowing the trunk version of ceilometer to continue to
work with folsom.

Change-Id: Ib59649ed6c04ea7218efa245dea428e0db4a16d0
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update use of nova config to work with folsom

The configuration API for nova changed between folsom and
grizzly. This change uses the folsom API if necessary,
allowing the trunk version of ceilometer to continue to
work with folsom.

Change-Id: Ib59649ed6c04ea7218efa245dea428e0db4a16d0
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Removes unnecessary db query for instance type

The instance type information is already available in the instance
hash. This removes a db query and also reduces the likelyhood of a
race condtion where the instance type could change between the
point where boot API call was made and the request hits the compute
node.

blueprint no-db-compute

Change-Id: I8372a8c88049a8dacef86a7034c6df94c40c3001

thanks again for yet another unit test.
I understand you want to push smalle patches for making reviews easier; nevertheless, when you have very strictly related, and small patches, it is my opinion that pushing them a single patch would be beneficial, as in this case multiple patches put more burden on reviewers.

Anyway, the patch looks good. I'm just not that sure about the change in attributes.py."}, {'account_id': 261, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:57:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(pushed publish button before finishing comments).

Can you point me to the particular pep8 principle for which you changed the logic? I cannot understand it from your commit message.'}, {'account_id': 1653, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:57:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 1994, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:57:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Salvatore, I thought you would prefer small patches. I'll pack them up and push a couple on the same commit.

If you look at "Programming Recommendations" in pep8, it states that "Comparisons to singletons like None should always be done with is or is not, never the equality operators."

The performance would be also much faster since it is comparing the hash of the objects. But I guess you gain only a couple of seconds comparing in the order of millions.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-12 16:57:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 16:57:43.000000000', 'message': 'Adds tests for attributes.is_attr_set

ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED and None are singleton objects

When conducting "is in" against a list of objects, they are compared using
unequal unless they are the same object.
http://docs.python.org/2/reference/expressions.html#in

According to PEP8, they should be compared by their id not value
Therefore the is_attr_set logic has changed to:
    return not (attribute is None or attribute is ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED)

Wrote unittests for is_attr_set

Change-Id: I2ebdd29564e5627b9e33b13a744948e8c9c0b9ce
'}]
commit_message:
Adds tests for attributes.is_attr_set

ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED and None are singleton objects

When conducting "is in" against a list of objects, they are compared using
unequal unless they are the same object.
http://docs.python.org/2/reference/expressions.html#in

According to PEP8, they should be compared by their id not value
Therefore the is_attr_set logic has changed to:
    return not (attribute is None or attribute is ATTR_NOT_SPECIFIED)

Wrote unittests for is_attr_set

Change-Id: I2ebdd29564e5627b9e33b13a744948e8c9c0b9ce

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 15:35:22.000000000', 'message': 'blueprint quantum-service-framework

Introduce basic support for multiple plugins within quantum:
1. Multiple plugins are loaded one per type
2. QuantumManager now holds dictionary {plugin_type: plugin_instance}
   Core plugin is stored there as well
3. Extensions are checked against all loaded plugins
4. Service plugins are specified in svc_plugins option in quantum.conf file
5. Provide basic interface for service plugins
6. Introduce dummy service plugin as example and PoC

Change-Id: I1d00d6f848937410bccd91c852ff0871a86d7bb8

blueprint quantum-service-framework

Add service-specific common prefix to all resources of given plugin.
Core/L3/existing resources get empty prefix, e.g. URLs are not changed.

Change-Id: I1d00d6f848937410bccd91c852ff0871a86d7bb8

bp/quantum-service-framework

fixes according to review comments.
Service type-related constants were moved to plugins/common/constants.py

Change-Id: I93f56f7cb3358a9e0fc6101b228aff35b2853e10
'}]
commit_message:
blueprint quantum-service-framework

Introduce basic support for multiple plugins within quantum:
1. Multiple plugins are loaded one per type
2. QuantumManager now holds dictionary {plugin_type: plugin_instance}
   Core plugin is stored there as well
3. Extensions are checked against all loaded plugins
4. Service plugins are specified in svc_plugins option in quantum.conf file
5. Provide basic interface for service plugins
6. Introduce dummy service plugin as example and PoC

Change-Id: I1d00d6f848937410bccd91c852ff0871a86d7bb8

blueprint quantum-service-framework

Add service-specific common prefix to all resources of given plugin.
Core/L3/existing resources get empty prefix, e.g. URLs are not changed.

Change-Id: I1d00d6f848937410bccd91c852ff0871a86d7bb8

bp/quantum-service-framework

fixes according to review comments.
Service type-related constants were moved to plugins/common/constants.py

Change-Id: I93f56f7cb3358a9e0fc6101b228aff35b2853e10

commit_message:
Switch from FLAGS to CONF in tests

Use the global CONF variable instead of FLAGS. This is purely a cleanup
since FLAGS is already just another reference to CONF.

We leave the nova.flags imports until a later cleanup commit since
removing them may cause unpredictable problems due to config options not
being registered.

Change-Id: Ic0168188dfe214fc81af04c8a9644d2d9f31600d

commit_message:
Switch from FLAGS to CONF in nova.compute

Use the global CONF variable instead of FLAGS. This is purely a cleanup
since FLAGS is already just another reference to CONF.

We leave the nova.flags imports until a later cleanup commit since
removing them may cause unpredictable problems due to config options not
being registered.

Change-Id: I0488b406dcf9f9459810337b62b6932d71a623a9

commit_message:
Remove bexar, cactus images and web content

These images are not being used in any current guides,
and the websites are being redirected to trunk at the webserver
level

Patch 2 removes some other images.

Change-Id: I39a2877eca6509d907e347e325facac54c15da4b

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-12 06:47:04.000000000', 'message': "Move RPC Setup section in quantum doc

fixes bug 1070360

As in the bug report, the RPC setup doc was before the server was
installed, causing confusion when requested to edit files that didn't
exist at the time. This change moves the section to be immediately
after the server installation.

Change-Id: I37ab92a052f1d7e9bcc653c10bca5d3583867943
"}]
commit_message:
Move RPC Setup section in quantum doc

fixes bug 1070360

As in the bug report, the RPC setup doc was before the server was
installed, causing confusion when requested to edit files that didn't
exist at the time. This change moves the section to be immediately
after the server installation.

Change-Id: I37ab92a052f1d7e9bcc653c10bca5d3583867943

fixes bug 988053

As in the bug request, people are often interested in running
services from different OpenStack projects on one piece of kit.

This patch adds a new section in common on co-locating services,
explaining the catches and things to look out for.
It's then linked from the compute install guide's architecture
section, and the install guide's assumption section.

Change-Id: I42a2843cb69fffd523a18143dc41e5275d9e5215
"}]
commit_message:
Add a section on co-locating services

fixes bug 988053

As in the bug request, people are often interested in running
services from different OpenStack projects on one piece of kit.

This patch adds a new section in common on co-locating services,
explaining the catches and things to look out for.
It's then linked from the compute install guide's architecture
section, and the install guide's assumption section.

Change-Id: I42a2843cb69fffd523a18143dc41e5275d9e5215

feel free to use that if you want to."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-19 20:12:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

I don't see how it passes.
I have recreated a test environment from scratch and it still fails for me. I think you need to retest it.

======================================================================
FAIL: test_GET_large_file_with_range (test.unit.proxy.test_server.TestObjectController)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):

----------------------------------------------------------------------'}, {'account_id': 2696, 'date': '2012-10-20 01:02:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

John and I observed differences in Python 2.6 on Ubuntu Lucid and various other platforms, specifically Python 2.7 on Oneiric (and maybe Precise?) with respect to how SIGPIPE is handled.  I don't remember the details, but I suspect that's what's going on here.

I'm guessing that you're using Python 2.6 or possibly 2.7 on Lucid, David?  If you try 2.7 on oneiric or possibly precise, I think you'll see the test fail without the code change."}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-20 20:53:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5410, 'date': '2012-10-20 20:56:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Add the pool flag in floating IP examples

fixes bug 971638

The --pool flag was missing from nova-manage floating create
examples. This adds it in.

commit_message:
Switch from FLAGS to CONF in nova.db

Use the global CONF variable instead of FLAGS. This is purely a cleanup
since FLAGS is already just another reference to CONF.

We leave the nova.flags imports until a later cleanup commit since
removing them may cause unpredictable problems due to config options not
being registered.

Change-Id: I4cd4bdb90d03d7069a419e4a7fbfde101940b5ec

- http://logs.openstack.org/15737/2/check/gate-openstack-common-python27/855 : SUCCESS
'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I think the value is that people can't do it wrong and not wrap it. Nova's gen_uuid function doesn't wrap it and so all over the code it is calling a one-liner helper function and then wrapping it. Glance has a helper that does wrap it with str. My reasoning was that if we have all these helpers, it should be in a common location. 

So I guess the simple value is so that nobody forgets to wrap uuid.uuid4() with str, even though they could very well not even use the helper. Anyone feel strongly one way or the other?"}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:26:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Works for me

commit_message:
Add generate_uuid to uuidutils.

Currently many projects have their own nearly identical methods for generating
uuids. This patch will change that.

Change-Id: I0af348ddbdea658331e8e701dcf1f8a12d968479

commit_message:
Clean up dictionary use in RPC drivers

Initialize the base dictionary before setting overrides.
Do not modify the argument passed to Connection.__init__.

Change-Id: I5479483509efe6966094b50af2703e566a99dace
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

commit_message:
Correcting openstack-common mv to oslo-incubator.

The earlier rename of openstack-common to oslo was incorrect; it should
have been oslo-incubator instead per the 2102-11-06 Project meeting log.
This change corrects its .gitreview file to match CI changes already
merged.

Change-Id: I9720387576a52654383bfc14f557ed1e06cc0a91

commit_message:
Update .gitreview for openstack.

Following a successful incubation period, the Ceilometer project is
moving from the StackForge ecosystem organization to become an official
OpenStack project. This handles the necessary update to .gitreview
reflecting the new remote name.

Change-Id: Iac0e2525df805e96ddff15cbe776603a7aabcf76

subject: Fixes a bug in api.metadata.base.lookup() on Windows
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3, 'name': 'Jenkins', 'username': 'jenkins'}, {'_account_id': 100, 'name': 'Johannes Erdfelt', 'email': 'johannes@erdfelt.com', 'username': 'johannes.erdfelt'}, {'_account_id': 1561, 'name': 'Russell Bryant', 'email': 'rbryant@redhat.com', 'username': 'russellb'}, {'_account_id': 2166, 'name': 'SmokeStack CI', 'username': 'smokestack', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 2271, 'name': 'Michael Still', 'email': 'mikal@stillhq.com', 'username': 'mikalstill'}, {'_account_id': 2750, 'name': 'Sean Dague', 'email': 'sean@dague.net', 'username': 'sdague'}, {'_account_id': 3185, 'name': 'Alessandro Pilotti', 'email': 'apilotti@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'alexpilotti'}, {'_account_id': 4393, 'name': 'Dan Smith', 'email': 'dms@danplanet.com', 'username': 'danms'}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:36:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

(2 inline comments)

A nit and a question inline."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:39:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

This really needs a bug opened and referenced in the commit message. Also, the first line should be shortened up. Please look at the HACKING.rst file for more details on that.

I'm not really a fan of this particular fix since it could convert legitimate \ into / silently (I don't have any immediate examples where that could happen however).

It appears the real problem is the use of os.path.normpath() on a URL path when os.path.normpath() is intended for paths on the local filesystem.

I wonder if we can fix this by using posixpath.normpath() instead. I'm not sure if the Windows python even installs it however."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:44:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:45:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Automatically re-added by Gerrit trivial rebase detection script."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:47:20.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

the path.os.normpath() is a big issue for us, as people are using it in all openstack projects to normalize URLs, with the resulting issues on Windows.

This will be solved when we'll have a working smokestack on Hyper-V but for the moment is a big issue on Windows."}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 5494, 'date': '2012-11-09 18:58:10.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

New patchset patch-id matches previous patchset, but commit message has changed.'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-09 19:17:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-09 20:17:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Works for me

Build successful

- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-merge/11765 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-docs/7499 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-pep8/12809 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-python26/8950 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-python27/9019 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/17952 : SUCCESS
- http://logs.openstack.org/15763/4/check/gate-nova-pylint/2711 : SUCCESS (non-voting)
'}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-09 20:37:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-09 21:20:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

So posixpath is an undocumented internal module for python which isn't really designed for urls - http://docs.python.org/2.7/library/undoc.html?highlight=posixpath

It looks like we were using normpath wrong for sure, but it seems like we should be using something which should be used for urls, and not using path functions on urls.

Temp -1 to see if there is a better option here."}, {'account_id': 100, 'date': '2012-11-09 21:34:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

posixpath is undocumented in the sense there is no explicit documentation, but even the linked page says there's no need to document it because it merely implements the os.path API.

http://docs.python.org/2/library/os.path.html even goes as far as encouraging using posixpath if the specific semantics are needed and the local implementation of os.path is not appropriate.

That said, I'm fine with using something designed for URL paths, but if that doesn't exist, I don't think we should shy away from posixpath.

I'll leave a +2 for now, but wait to see if Sean finds a better option."}, {'account_id': 1561, 'date': '2012-11-09 23:17:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

FWIW, I did have that concern about posixpath at first as well, since it looked like it was something that shouldn't be used directly.  What convinced me was the notes at the top of the os.path docs page.

I didn't go looking for something else that was designed for URLs, though."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-10 11:49:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

http:// stackoverflow.com/questions/10584861/canonize-normalize-an-url-in-python - it looks like the internal urlparse.urljoin can be used for this, which seems like it would be better.'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-10 13:56:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Sean,

from http://docs.python.org/2/library/os.path.html:

Since different operating systems have different path name conventions, there are several versions of this module in the standard library. The os.path module is always the path module suitable for the operating system Python is running on (omissis).

posixpath for UNIX-style paths
ntpath for Windows paths

So by using directly posixpath, we preserve the expected behavior by the previous implementation.'}, {'account_id': 3185, 'date': '2012-11-10 16:38:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

One more point for the usage of posixpath.normpath():

From the posixpath doc:

Some of this can actually be useful on non-Posix systems too, e.g.
for manipulation of the pathname component of URLs.

http://hg.python.org/cpython/file/9214f8440c44/Lib/posixpath.py'}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-11 15:42:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: No score

If everyone else thinks using the path functions are fine, that's ok with me. Just seemed we should try to use url specific code here, as things like turning spaces into '%20' wouldn't be covered by just path manip."}, {'account_id': 2271, 'date': '2012-11-11 22:39:41.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Looks good to me (core reviewer); Approved

'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 22:39:56.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: No score

Starting gate jobs.
https://jenkins.openstack.org/zuul/status'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-11 23:01:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified

Build successful

commit_message:
Fixes a bug in api.metadata.base.lookup() on Windows

Fixes Bug #1077125

api.metadata.base.lookup() uses os.path.normpath() to normalize urls.
This doesn't work on Windows as it transforms "/" in "\".

The fix solves the issue, but os.path.normpath() should never be used
to normalize urls.

Change-Id: I83d0795d5875acac5fe9bd543f9ca9b4a3e2c8d5

commit_message:
Update .gitreview for oslo.

At the Design Summit it was decided that the OpenStack common modules
would be named Oslo as part of an effort to convert them into a core
project housing a collection of library dependencies. This handles the
necessary update to .gitreview reflecting the new remote name.

commit_message:
Add BoxGrinder, remove Condenser, add cloud-init details

Add a section on BoxGrinder for creating virtual machine images.

Remove reference to Condenser, which no longer exists.

Add info about how to set the user to copy the key into in cloud-init.

Change-Id: Ib47c9a610dbe70014c6412a2f491104e04060833

"}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-08 19:06:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

I think you triggered the reason we didn't use it before, it's not an drop in interface replacement. The one mysql test is now failing."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-11-08 19:14:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

GAH. I will contact geert and tell him it's broken. The _dialect_ should be a drop in replacement imho"}, {'account_id': 159, 'date': '2012-11-09 20:55:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

I know this definitely breaks "db sync"... and it /might/ break other things too.'}, {'account_id': 360, 'date': '2012-11-10 03:47:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

Couple of thoughts here...

If we require MySQL-python in production code it makes sense to use the same thing for tests (that to me is the point of tests).

Is the motivation here to make people running tests on OSX happy? Is MySQL-python a show stopper there?

Also, we just recently adding this requirement to test-requires again anyway. Rather than play musical MySQL libraries I would rather just remove it again entirely. It seems you could even update unit test runners in Jenkins, etc. to install MySQL-python manually and continue to run these tests (with the MySQL driver) even though we don't explicitly require it for all development environments."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-11-10 20:15:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Well - (and I'm going to abandon this for now) - this was actually step one in seeing if we could move to using connector python across the board - because I'm pretty sure it would play WAY nicer with eventlet (we're doing a lot of hacks currently to try to deal with the C-library nature of MySQL-python)

BUT - if it doesn't actually work in the first place, then investigating whether or not it can work in production is a moot point."}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2012-11-10 20:15:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned

Suck.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 17:48:37.000000000', 'message': 'Move to using pure-python connector for tests.

Having MySQL-python in test-requires makes it hard for people to do things.
Specifically, it makes bcwaldon unhappy. We only use it for one thing, which
is testing schema changes, so performance issues are silly. Replace MySQLdb
with mysql-connector-python, which is pure-python, to make virtualenvs
easier to deal with.

As a note - we should consider whether or not this should be used as our
default recommended mysql connection method - as it should play MUCH nicer
with eventlet.

Change-Id: I80f996fdc294ac8e58cc5b07deada6409c925a09
'}]
commit_message:
Move to using pure-python connector for tests.

Having MySQL-python in test-requires makes it hard for people to do things.
Specifically, it makes bcwaldon unhappy. We only use it for one thing, which
is testing schema changes, so performance issues are silly. Replace MySQLdb
with mysql-connector-python, which is pure-python, to make virtualenvs
easier to deal with.

As a note - we should consider whether or not this should be used as our
default recommended mysql connection method - as it should play MUCH nicer
with eventlet.

Change-Id: I80f996fdc294ac8e58cc5b07deada6409c925a09

commit_message:
Fixes setup compatibility issue on Windows

Fixes Bug #1052161

"python setup.py build" fails on Windows due to a hardcoded shell path:
/bin/sh

Change-Id: I412b1f9f263b781e9f2ae4a110bc84c653ef3c7e

Switch bind9 agent to a driver based implementation.

Fixes bug #1074091
Fixes bug #1077023

[{'created': '2012-11-05 00:10:32.000000000', 'message': "Install and configure python-heatclient.

This uses the new REST API. It installs a client executable called 'heat'.
The old heat client in the heat repo has been renamed to heat-cfn.

Change-Id: I7bc8662c531e3639cc940a44df96ff426ac3aada
"}]
commit_message:
Install and configure python-heatclient.

This uses the new REST API. It installs a client executable called 'heat'.
The old heat client in the heat repo has been renamed to heat-cfn.

Change-Id: I7bc8662c531e3639cc940a44df96ff426ac3aada

also fixes openstack-common style

(33 inline comments)

Getting close to something acceptable, but lots of cleanup work we can still do

My big issue with the current patch is that we're adding a separate code path in so many places - we should make it so this "node name" concept applies when using any virt driver, even when there is only a single node per service'}, {'account_id': 1247, 'date': '2012-11-02 12:36:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

Just a note on terminology, because it's kind of confusing

It's bare-metal not baremetal. Also, BareMetal not Baremetal

A bare-metal machine provisioned as a result of a "run instance" API request is known as a "bare-metal instance"

A bare-metal machine that is available for scheduling is known as a "bare-metal compute node"

The service responsible for provisioning bare-metal compute nodes using the bare-metal virt driver is known as the "bare-metal compute service"


And then, more generally ...

A compute service is responsible for 1 or more compute nodes

A compute service is responsible for provisioning instances on a compute node

The scheduler is responsible for choosing both the compute service and the compute node when scheduling an instance'}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-11-05 11:07:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 17.'}, {'account_id': 3068, 'date': '2012-11-05 11:09:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16: (37 inline comments)

Sean & Mark: I modified the points you commented, please check the new patchset'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-05 11:26:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 17: Works for me

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-10-01 20:13:20.000000000', 'message': "Updated scheduler and compute for multiple capabilities.

Part 1 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

This patch includes updates on scheduler and compute codes for
multiple bare-metal capabilities. In bare-metal provisioning,
a bare-metal nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal nodes
where instances are provisioned. Nova DB's compute_nodes entry
needs to be created for each bare-metal node, and a scheduler can
choose an appropriate bare-metal node to provision an instance.
With this patch, one service entry with multiple bare-metal compute_node
entries is registered at the start of bare-metal nova-compute.
Distinct 'node name' is given for each bare-metal node.
For this purpose, we extended FilterScheduler to put <nodename>
to Nova DB's instance_system_metadata,
and bare-metal nova-compute use <host> and <hypervisor_hostname>
instead of <host> to identify the bare-metal node to provision the instance.
Also, 'capability’ is extended from a dictionary to a list of dictionaries
to describe the multiple capabilities of the multiple bare-metal nodes.

Change-Id: I527febe4dbd887b2e6596ce7226c1ae3386e2ae6
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

Distinct 'node name' is given for each bare-metal node.
For this purpose, we added a new column "node" to "instances" table in
Nova DB and extended FilterScheduler to put <nodename> to the column.
And bare-metal nova-compute use <host> and <hypervisor_hostname>
instead of <host> to identify the bare-metal node to provision the instance.
Also, 'capability’ is extended from a dictionary to a list of dictionaries
to describe the multiple capabilities of the multiple bare-metal nodes.

Change-Id: I527febe4dbd887b2e6596ce7226c1ae3386e2ae6
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

'}, {'created': '2012-11-05 11:07:09.000000000', 'message': 'Updated scheduler and compute for multiple capabilities.

Part 1 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

This patch includes updates on scheduler and compute codes for
multiple capabilities. This feature is needed in bare-metal
provisioning which is implemented in later patches --- a bare-metal
nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal nodes where instances are
provisioned. Nova DB's compute_nodes entry needs to be created for
each bare-metal node, and a scheduler can choose an appropriate
bare-metal node to provision an instance.

With this patch, one service entry with multiple compute_node entries
can be registered by nova-compute. Distinct 'node name' is given for
each node and is stored at compute_node['hypervisor_hostname'].
And we added a new column "node" to "instances" table in Nova DB to
associate instances with compute_node. FilterScheduler puts <nodename>
to the column when it provisions the instance. And nova-computes
respect <nodename> when run/stop instances and when calculate
resources.

Also, 'capability’ is extended from a dictionary to a list of
dictionaries to describe the multiple capabilities of the multiple
nodes.

Change-Id: I527febe4dbd887b2e6596ce7226c1ae3386e2ae6
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>

commit_message:
Updated scheduler and compute for multiple capabilities.

Part 1 of 6: blueprint general-bare-metal-provisioning-framework.

This patch includes updates on scheduler and compute codes for
multiple capabilities. This feature is needed in bare-metal
provisioning which is implemented in later patches --- a bare-metal
nova-compute manages multiple bare-metal nodes where instances are
provisioned. Nova DB's compute_nodes entry needs to be created for
each bare-metal node, and a scheduler can choose an appropriate
bare-metal node to provision an instance.

With this patch, one service entry with multiple compute_node entries
can be registered by nova-compute. Distinct 'node name' is given for
each node and is stored at compute_node['hypervisor_hostname'].
And we added a new column "node" to "instances" table in Nova DB to
associate instances with compute_node. FilterScheduler puts <nodename>
to the column when it provisions the instance. And nova-computes
respect <nodename> when run/stop instances and when calculate
resources.

Also, 'capability’ is extended from a dictionary to a list of
dictionaries to describe the multiple capabilities of the multiple
nodes.

Change-Id: I527febe4dbd887b2e6596ce7226c1ae3386e2ae6
Co-authored-by: Mikyung Kang <mkkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: David Kang <dkang@isi.edu>
Co-authored-by: Ken Igarashi <igarashik@nttdocomo.co.jp>
Co-authored-by: Arata Notsu <notsu@virtualtech.jp>

commit_message:
blueprint support-resource-count-api

It needs the api what can response just number of instances, volumes, keypairs and so on NOT all list of them for better performance.
the api should use count(*) query on db side.
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+spec/support-resource-count-api

-------------------
Files:
-------------------
db/api.py
db/sqlalchemy/api.py
There are 3 methods for resource-count.(instance_count_by_project,volume_count_by_project,key_pair_count_by_project)

api/openstack/compute/contrib/resource_count.py
This file will be executed when some users request REST API about resource_count.

tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_resource_count.py
unnittest file for 3 count_by_project

	new file:   nova/api/openstack/compute/contrib/resource_count.py
	modified:   nova/db/api.py
	modified:   nova/db/sqlalchemy/api.py
	new file:   nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_resource_count.py

Change-Id: I23476325ce5f5a71fbba3a34c6bc5e3194bc6214

move python-cinderclient to pip-requires

python-cinderclient is now actually a requirement, move
this from test-requires to pip-requires to reflect that.

Fixes bug #1074085

commit_message:
Make initial structural changes to keystoneclient in preparation
to moving auth_token here from keystone.  No functional change
should occur from this commit (even though it did refresh a newer copy
of openstack.common.setup.py, none of the newer updates are in
functions called from this client)

blueprint authtoken-to-keystoneclient-repo

Change-Id: Ie54feb73e0e34b56400fdaa8a8f876f9284bac27

recheck'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-09 16:15:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Looks good to me, but question about the impact - after we've done this, will the Folsom -> Grizzly database schema migrations be impacted? (i.e. will you still be able to smoothly translate from one to another)?

It looks like you're manually specifying the schema that was otherwise generated by the objects, but don't know enough detail about SQLAlchemy to be sure that's what is happening."}, {'account_id': 4, 'date': '2012-11-09 16:39:43.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

That's exactly what I'm doing -- I did a 'select * from sqlite_master' to check the schema produced before & after this change, and made sure they were identical. So, this change should have no impact (except maybe tables being created in a different order, which shouldn't matter).

The problem with the existing migration was that it was automatically creating tables that *should* be created by later migrations (ones which don't exist yet... e.g. the domain table introduced in the v3 identity impl). I wouldn't call that a bug because it's breaking code that hasn't merged yet :)"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-09 16:43:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

commit_message:
Use the right subprocess based on os monkeypatch

This works around the following eventlet bug:

https://bitbucket.org/which_linden/eventlet/issue/92

by using the green version of Popen if os has been
monkeypatched. It also has the side effect of making the ssl
calls not block the reactor for workers that use eventlet.

Change-Id: I1457237f52310f0536fbcdcaa42174b17e8edbf5

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-10 00:49:43.000000000', 'message': "Make swift-bench use less memory with large object sizes.

Before, swift-bench would create a string of the right size and pass
that to [direct_]put_object. Uploading 5 GB objects w/concurrency of
4? Hope you've got a spare 20 GB of RAM in that machine.

Now it lazily generates chunks (of size 64 KiB) to send. In my limited
testing, this keeps RAM usage low while not impacting speed.

There's backwards-compatibility code in
direct_client.direct_put_object for any callers who are still passing
in strings. There aren't any such in Swift's codebase, though. All one
of those callers now pass an iterable.

Fixes bug 911925.

Change-Id: I40669fc00c7fb6699d8fb514e1be9b69436eca42
"}]
commit_message:
Make swift-bench use less memory with large object sizes.

Before, swift-bench would create a string of the right size and pass
that to [direct_]put_object. Uploading 5 GB objects w/concurrency of
4? Hope you've got a spare 20 GB of RAM in that machine.

Now it lazily generates chunks (of size 64 KiB) to send. In my limited
testing, this keeps RAM usage low while not impacting speed.

There's backwards-compatibility code in
direct_client.direct_put_object for any callers who are still passing
in strings. There aren't any such in Swift's codebase, though. All one
of those callers now pass an iterable.

Fixes bug 911925.

Change-Id: I40669fc00c7fb6699d8fb514e1be9b69436eca42

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 22:04:01.000000000', 'message': 'Make DELETE requests to expired objects return 404.

It is already the case that a DELETE of a deleted object results in a
404, and GET/HEAD/POSTs to both expired and deleted objects result in
404s. However, a DELETE of an expired object resulted in a 202. This
change makes it consistent with the other verbs.

Fixes bug 1076245.

Change-Id: I5f4f0df17fed93929c00c4cbd00579e70aa82201
'}]
commit_message:
Make DELETE requests to expired objects return 404.

It is already the case that a DELETE of a deleted object results in a
404, and GET/HEAD/POSTs to both expired and deleted objects result in
404s. However, a DELETE of an expired object resulted in a 202. This
change makes it consistent with the other verbs.

Fixes bug 1076245.

Change-Id: I5f4f0df17fed93929c00c4cbd00579e70aa82201

commit_message:
give swob default content-type

This should fix up the few remaining API regressions from swob, by giving all
responses a default content-type of "text/html; charset=UTF-8".

Change-Id: I7e7f7cbf46d543c7f6d965d74b06eef3d88c83b4

commit_message:
use Host: for location rewrites

If the Host header is available, use it for making relative URLs absolute.
Otherwise, continue using SERVER_NAME.

Change-Id: Ib25d542b154d8a74081e1d766e8da1ee240e1247

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 22:04:00.000000000', 'message': "Use computed size on object PUT, not fstat.

The object server knows the size of the file on disk already since
it's counted the bytes as they were written out. There's no need to go
ask the filesystem.

This also lets object PUTs work when the filesystem is some crazy,
non-POSIX thing that doesn't always give the right answers from
fstat(). See bug 904723 for a case when this happened.

Fixes bug 904723.

Change-Id: I7b62af55b6aac54b310ab1373364755eba667198
"}]
commit_message:
Use computed size on object PUT, not fstat.

The object server knows the size of the file on disk already since
it's counted the bytes as they were written out. There's no need to go
ask the filesystem.

This also lets object PUTs work when the filesystem is some crazy,
non-POSIX thing that doesn't always give the right answers from
fstat(). See bug 904723 for a case when this happened.

Fixes bug 904723.

Change-Id: I7b62af55b6aac54b310ab1373364755eba667198

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 22:03:59.000000000', 'message': "Fixed bugs with internal client and object expirer

These bug fixes are lumped together because they all caused problems
with the object expirer doing its job.

There was a bug with the internal client doing listings that happened
to run across a Unicode object name for use as a marker.

There was a bug with the object expirer not utf8 encoding object
names it got from json listings, causing deletes to fail.

There was a bug with the object expirer url quoting object names when
calling the internal client's make_request, when make_request already
handles that.

Change-Id: I1cee0de01ac570e975ee181bcc65a2d48f0719cf
"}]
commit_message:
Fixed bugs with internal client and object expirer

These bug fixes are lumped together because they all caused problems
with the object expirer doing its job.

There was a bug with the internal client doing listings that happened
to run across a Unicode object name for use as a marker.

There was a bug with the object expirer not utf8 encoding object
names it got from json listings, causing deletes to fail.

There was a bug with the object expirer url quoting object names when
calling the internal client's make_request, when make_request already
handles that.

Change-Id: I1cee0de01ac570e975ee181bcc65a2d48f0719cf

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 21:19:29.000000000', 'message': "Make swift-bench use less memory with large object sizes.

Before, swift-bench would create a string of the right size and pass
that to [direct_]put_object. Uploading 5 GB objects w/concurrency of
4? Hope you've got a spare 20 GB of RAM in that machine.

Now it lazily generates chunks (of size 64 KiB) to send. In my limited
testing, this keeps RAM usage low while not impacting speed.

Fixes bug 911925.

Change-Id: I40669fc00c7fb6699d8fb514e1be9b69436eca42
"}, {'created': '2012-11-09 19:12:42.000000000', 'message': "Make swift-bench use less memory with large object sizes.

Before, swift-bench would create a string of the right size and pass
that to [direct_]put_object. Uploading 5 GB objects w/concurrency of
4? Hope you've got a spare 20 GB of RAM in that machine.

Now it lazily generates chunks (of size 64 KiB) to send. In my limited
testing, this keeps RAM usage low while not impacting speed.

There's backwards-compatibility code in
direct_client.direct_put_object for any callers who are still passing
in strings. There aren't any such in Swift's codebase, though. All one
of those callers now pass an iterable.

Fixes bug 911925.

Change-Id: I40669fc00c7fb6699d8fb514e1be9b69436eca42
"}]
commit_message:
Make swift-bench use less memory with large object sizes.

Before, swift-bench would create a string of the right size and pass
that to [direct_]put_object. Uploading 5 GB objects w/concurrency of
4? Hope you've got a spare 20 GB of RAM in that machine.

Now it lazily generates chunks (of size 64 KiB) to send. In my limited
testing, this keeps RAM usage low while not impacting speed.

There's backwards-compatibility code in
direct_client.direct_put_object for any callers who are still passing
in strings. There aren't any such in Swift's codebase, though. All one
of those callers now pass an iterable.

Fixes bug 911925.

Change-Id: I40669fc00c7fb6699d8fb514e1be9b69436eca42

[{'created': '2012-11-09 21:30:58.000000000', 'message': 'Increase VOLUME_BACKING_FILE_SIZE to 5G.

Apparently 4G is not enough space to run the tempest tests in all cases.
http://logs.openstack.org/15738/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/17885/
is an example of when 4G is not enough space to run the tempest tests,
"Insufficient free extents (255) in volume group stack-volumes: 256
required".

Get around this by generously over allocating an extra gigabyte of
space.

Change-Id: I22876ed26dc7011bee22269dafc533929dff330a
'}]
commit_message:
Increase VOLUME_BACKING_FILE_SIZE to 5G.

Apparently 4G is not enough space to run the tempest tests in all cases.
http://logs.openstack.org/15738/1/check/gate-tempest-devstack-vm/17885/
is an example of when 4G is not enough space to run the tempest tests,
"Insufficient free extents (255) in volume group stack-volumes: 256
required".

Get around this by generously over allocating an extra gigabyte of
space.

Change-Id: I22876ed26dc7011bee22269dafc533929dff330a

A bit of self-review and/or solicitation of advice (this is my first change to any OpenStack project, so guidance would be appreciated):

I had a look at how I could update the unit tests to test for the cases covered here, but it looks like the layer at which validation occurs is stubbed out in the tests -- so validation would have to be duplicated in the test stubs (ie, there would be no test of this change).

Would it be useful to make the unit tests test more fine-grained units? Is that something that should be done along with this change, or separately (with this change depending on that?)?'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-10-30 20:10:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Works for me

'}, {'account_id': 177, 'date': '2012-10-30 20:41:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ideally utils.is_valid_boolstr would have it's own test in test_utils.py. 

For this change a test should be added to make sure that when is_valid_boolstr returns false that an InvalidInput is raised. There is a test_instance_type_create in nova/tests/test_instance_types.py that this test could be modelled after.

You are right though, there is a lot of work to do to make the unit tests more granular (as they should be)."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-10-31 00:22:39.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

It looks like some test coverage of just the instance_types file is needed. I don't know if tests need to be refactored so much as a few new tests for instance_types.py need to be added. That said, your patch makes sense to me.

I would have considered adding a test to:

tests/api/openstack/compute/contrib/test_flavor_manage.py

that stubs create to return InvalidInput to make sure the api extension handles the exception properly, but it looks like the api extension just passes the InvalidInput up to the default FaultWrapper anyway."}, {'account_id': 1030, 'date': '2012-10-31 06:12:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
Validate is-public parameter to flavor creation

Check that the is-public parameter to flavor creation is either a
boolean or a string representing a boolean, and raise an error
otherwise.

Fixes bug 1059414

Change-Id: Ic0764f0ee407d40bb5d14c1e92de4bf033bd657f

[{'created': '2012-11-08 15:55:28.000000000', 'message': 'Simplify topic handling in network rpcapi.

rpc.queue_get_for() can now handle host=None.  Simplify some of the
topic handling logic in the network rpcapi to take advantage of this.

Change-Id: I1fc5b2e7370f7c5440bd4beaae007a2126e9f645
'}]
commit_message:
Simplify topic handling in network rpcapi.

rpc.queue_get_for() can now handle host=None.  Simplify some of the
topic handling logic in the network rpcapi to take advantage of this.

Change-Id: I1fc5b2e7370f7c5440bd4beaae007a2126e9f645

commit_message:
Some more minor fixes and additions.

Add a Cinder trouble-shooting section
Clarify a couple points in the cinder install
Add SolidFire driver info
Give a brief exaplanation of Cinder vs Nova-Volume

Patchset adds xml:ids where needed and minor fixes.
Also xi:include for the cinder troubleshooting file.

Change-Id: Ic66b8c7182bc3e53a72fbd06daab819e35e52270

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 23:30:10.000000000', 'message': 'Make DELETE requests to expired objects return 404.

It is already the case that a DELETE of a deleted object results in a
404, and GET/HEAD/POSTs to both expired and deleted objects result in
404s. However, a DELETE of an expired object resulted in a 202. This
change makes it consistent with the other verbs.

Fixes bug 1076245.

Change-Id: I793e62d72461a4fb9fb3404e10658ddcc4c3a7a6
'}]
commit_message:
Make DELETE requests to expired objects return 404.

It is already the case that a DELETE of a deleted object results in a
404, and GET/HEAD/POSTs to both expired and deleted objects result in
404s. However, a DELETE of an expired object resulted in a 202. This
change makes it consistent with the other verbs.

Fixes bug 1076245.

Change-Id: I793e62d72461a4fb9fb3404e10658ddcc4c3a7a6

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 15:43:01.000000000', 'message': 'Set the rabbit_durable_queues to match local consumers

Due to a problematic bug in Glance (https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1074132),
I was unable to get stack.sh to complete successfully. The workaround on the
Glance bug was to set the rabbit_durable_queues value to match the setting
of the local Rabbit consumers and exchanges.

This patch merely looks for any consumer or exchange that
is durable and ensures that the default durable_rabbit_queues
config option of False is set to True in that case.

Change-Id: Ia5a165a5a06d11d1fe6492ca32139972d49d3a1e
'}]
commit_message:
Set the rabbit_durable_queues to match local consumers

Due to a problematic bug in Glance (https://bugs.launchpad.net/glance/+bug/1074132),
I was unable to get stack.sh to complete successfully. The workaround on the
Glance bug was to set the rabbit_durable_queues value to match the setting
of the local Rabbit consumers and exchanges.

This patch merely looks for any consumer or exchange that
is durable and ensures that the default durable_rabbit_queues
config option of False is set to True in that case.

Change-Id: Ia5a165a5a06d11d1fe6492ca32139972d49d3a1e

commit_message:
Import lockutils and fileutils from openstack-common

File lock function is needed to support iptables-based security group
implementation.

This is used by bp quantum-security-groups-iptables
Change-Id: Id9c116a1e10e5c240913fae7a127110b806eff0f

commit_message:
give swob default content-type

This should fix up the few remaining API regressions from swob, by giving all
responses a default content-type of "text/html; charset=UTF-8".

Change-Id: Ib3b859e63c5e8c4af6f7fe535947402b5df57399

commit_message:
Fixes a bug in nova.utils, due to Windows compatibility issues.

Fixes Bug #1077121

subprocess.Popen() does not support preexec_fn and close_fds = True on
Windows

Change-Id: I69697b692b982c7cf786f52cc57f95b4819b50d8

[{'created': '2012-11-09 17:24:53.000000000', 'message': "Ensure BASE_SQL_CONN is set properly in tools/configure_tempest.sh

Recent changes to enable more than just MySQL to be used
in devstack moved some setup stuff to lib/database. While
this file was source'd in tools/configure_tempes.sh, the
BASE_SQL_CONN variable was not being set because
lib/database/initialize_database_backends was not called.

Change-Id: I53c3302097a94c842860fcb781e21383150bde7f
fixes: LP bug#1077056
"}, {'created': '2012-11-09 18:23:55.000000000', 'message': "Ensure BASE_SQL_CONN is set properly in tools/configure_tempest.sh

Recent changes to enable more than just MySQL to be used
in devstack moved some setup stuff to lib/database. While
this file was source'd in tools/configure_tempes.sh, the
BASE_SQL_CONN variable was not being set because
lib/database/initialize_database_backends was not called.

Change-Id: I53c3302097a94c842860fcb781e21383150bde7f
fixes: LP bug#1077056
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure BASE_SQL_CONN is set properly in tools/configure_tempest.sh

Recent changes to enable more than just MySQL to be used
in devstack moved some setup stuff to lib/database. While
this file was source'd in tools/configure_tempes.sh, the
BASE_SQL_CONN variable was not being set because
lib/database/initialize_database_backends was not called.

Change-Id: I53c3302097a94c842860fcb781e21383150bde7f
fixes: LP bug#1077056

factoring out a latent bug where sys.exit was conditionally called
without first importing it.

'}]
commit_message:
Fix latent bug in test.

* test.py: Changed to assert a particular path in the configuration,
factoring out a latent bug where sys.exit was conditionally called
without first importing it.

Change-Id: Iaf8a029d226777f38004527802494366a89c943d

This fixes a small change introduced by swob.  It shouldn't actually be

commit_message:
add charset to DELETEs

Or anything that uses best_response.
This fixes a small change introduced by swob.  It shouldn't actually be
important, but I'd rather not change the API at all if we can avoid it.

Change-Id: I16b49597570223cab3ff2701c59588608bfa941a

commit_message:
Make tox.ini run pep8/hacking checks on bin.

This updates the pep8 hacking checks in our tox.ini file so that
we are also scanning the bin directory for HACKING violations.

Change-Id: I4b010ef4dd799f0afe0fcd56c823a611021e8f60

subject: Allow devstack to run without Nova
messages: [{'account_id': 1132, 'date': '2012-11-09 17:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Abandoned\n\nSuperseded by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/15750/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 17:46:05.000000000', 'message': 'Allow devstack to run without Nova

Certain places in stack.sh assumed nova was enabled and
would call add_nova_opt. This patch ensures Nova is
actually enabled before making those calls.

Change-Id: I3d808a6d2d20bf3cc49529eeddf44fd59c14ef00
'}]
commit_message:
Allow devstack to run without Nova

Certain places in stack.sh assumed nova was enabled and
would call add_nova_opt. This patch ensures Nova is
actually enabled before making those calls.

Change-Id: I3d808a6d2d20bf3cc49529eeddf44fd59c14ef00

commit_message:
Remove generic topic support from filter scheduler

The only topic that we do scheduling on is 'compute', so clean up all of
the cases where we were checking this.

Change-Id: If16eaf48a89342ca99a741c25679389e706e0e48

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-07 23:48:30.000000000', 'message': 'Remove nova-volume DB

*  Remove volume calls from nova.db.api
*  Remove volume calls from nova.db.sqlalchemy.api
*  Remove tables from nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py
*  Remove Xen Storage Manager Volume Driver code
*  No migration to preserve data in unused tables

commit_message:
Remove nova-volume DB

*  Remove volume calls from nova.db.api
*  Remove volume calls from nova.db.sqlalchemy.api
*  Remove tables from nova/db/sqlalchemy/models.py
*  Remove Xen Storage Manager Volume Driver code
*  No migration to preserve data in unused tables
*  Remove quota support for volumes

DocImpact

part of bp delete-nova-volume

Change-Id: I2c82c96d67f3746e5de28f917dd8ceb0c8037e27

commit_message:
Add indication when quantum server started.

Bug #1076834

Option values are printed in two phases due to our
system's starting way. Last print will print out all
option values included in all config files.

In the end when quantum server started, we have an
indication for it.

Change-Id: I4ed9952c94fe74ea946733dc3a94cb2bb2aba37c

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 16:52:25.000000000', 'message': 'Explicitly include versioninfo in tarball.

The most recent sync of openstack-common setup.py/version.py code
seems to have cause quantum/versioninfo to disappear from the tarball.
(see git commit d65bca8)

This updates MANIFEST.in to explicitly include that file and seems
to resolve the issue.

Fixes LP Bug #1077035.

Change-Id: I5fb395c15ea998da00b11e66947d1b1ea3665ea0
'}]
commit_message:
Explicitly include versioninfo in tarball.

The most recent sync of openstack-common setup.py/version.py code
seems to have cause quantum/versioninfo to disappear from the tarball.
(see git commit d65bca8)

This updates MANIFEST.in to explicitly include that file and seems
to resolve the issue.

Fixes LP Bug #1077035.

Change-Id: I5fb395c15ea998da00b11e66947d1b1ea3665ea0

commit_message:
Use openstack versioning

1. Add the version module from openstack.common.
2. Create a ceilometer/version.py to set up the
   version info.
3. Update setup.py from openstack.common.
4. Update documentation build to use the version module
   directly instead of running setup.py to get the version.
5. Update setup.py to use the new version module.

Change-Id: I9d8be62b8ece75090bf335d27adb59a46e3d6263
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug.hellmann@dreamhost.com>

attribute which now should be through direct attribute
access to 'file_format' instead.

Change-Id: Id4c12b43b389b2fd2300d02743db17cf48b38e8f
"}]
commit_message:
Another case of dictionary access

Fixes bug 1076114 which was using the old dictionary
access for getting the qemu image info 'file format'
attribute which now should be through direct attribute
access to 'file_format' instead.

Change-Id: Id4c12b43b389b2fd2300d02743db17cf48b38e8f

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-09 11:16:05.000000000', 'message': "Switch to UUID for the Stack primary key.

For the migrate upgrade, existing integer keys remain and any subsequent stack
will be assigned a uuid.

For a migrate downgrade, it should work fine if there have been no stacks added
since ugrade. Added stacks will have their IDs 'truncated' back to an integer
which will require some manual fixup after downgrade.

Change-Id: Ib882bece911fcbc96fffab16a9f0e5ce3cb55fed
"}]
commit_message:
Switch to UUID for the Stack primary key.

For the migrate upgrade, existing integer keys remain and any subsequent stack
will be assigned a uuid.

For a migrate downgrade, it should work fine if there have been no stacks added
since ugrade. Added stacks will have their IDs 'truncated' back to an integer
which will require some manual fixup after downgrade.

Change-Id: Ib882bece911fcbc96fffab16a9f0e5ce3cb55fed

Clean up executable modules

Disabled execution of modules loaded by execution files in bin
Changed file bit mode of modules which are executable

Change-Id: If8a3378c79bb5bfcde1b93066c6b2c0a3d1107ad

commit_message:
Scheduler API clean up and refactor

Unlike Nova scheduler, which has to consider serving compute and volume
scheduling, Cinder scheduler only serves volume scheduling, so there's no
need to keep generic interface 'schedule'. Instead, 'schedule_create_volume'
is added (if missing) to manager/driver class and chance/simple scheduler
driver implementation.

Also this patch changes the interface between API service and scheduler to
allow more information about volume is passed to scheduler for advanced
scheduling while maintained backward compatibility. And this change bumps
scheduler RPC API to version 1.2.

Change-Id: I42be05675cd73f89a03c84105ec512d7ee4f3c3a

"}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-01 05:35:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Do not merge

Not sure we want to go this route, but if we do, adding the google ip code is definitely a no-no. You should be able to do what you need with netaddr which is already a dependency.'}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2012-11-01 05:52:28.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

If you're going to get debate on whether this is even a good idea I suggest you propose it on the mailing list.

Your upgrade/downgrade does nothing other than convert the column type between binary and string.  That's not going to work without also converting the value within the column.  The old value is a nicely formatted IP address.  The new value is binary packed.  You'll need to do more than simply change the column type."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-01 12:17:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

There seems like a lot of loss of usability in the database by making these values not human readable in dumps, for a really uncertain amount of performance gain. I really think that a proposed change like this needs to come in with real numbers showing it's better in practice (could actually be noticed in a real working set), not just in theory."}, {'account_id': 3217, 'date': '2012-11-01 13:26:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

Sean: the obvious thing it makes possible is a significant improvement in the way the floating IP code works.  There are better tactics available if you can do MAX(), >, <, ORDER BY...  (For instance: do not add yourself an IPv6 /64 floating IP range at the moment unless you want to run out of memory, disk and time before the end of the universe.)

I agree about the dumps, though.  My preferred solution would be to use something that the database likes - for instance, MySQL has INET_ATON functions, which at least means you can SELECT INET_NTOA(ip_column) ... and PostgreSQL has an actual inet column type.  (SQLite, you're stuffed.)  Difficult to implement, though."}, {'account_id': 2750, 'date': '2012-11-01 14:07:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

So I think that brings up a different issue, is that for IPv6 handling, the idea of putting all possibles in the database completely breaks, and that just has to be done better. :)

But I think the mysql inet aton is a spurious argument, because it doesn't support IPv6. If a database has a good way to natively store inet info (like postgresql), that's a different story than us binary packing on the code side."}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-09 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Abandoned

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}, {'account_id': 9, 'date': '2012-11-09 06:03:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7:

code review expired after 1 week of no activity after a negative review, it can be restored using the `Restore Change` button under the Patch Set on the web interface'}]

change the ip from string to bytes in databse

Bug #994150

use typeDecorator to transform ip address between int and string
change sqlalchemy models to map address as int

While I support the approach, I worry about using authtoken as a top level class/package name in the client, considering that we are about to move the auth_token middleware to the client as well.  The naming of the package in the server is token, and we should probably keep them in sync.

We probably need to address the overall package structure.  Under keystoneclient We currently have:
middleware openstack generic common contrib locale v2_0.  Should the token namespace be added at this level?"}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-01 01:55:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-01 01:56:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-08 05:10:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

comment to myself to keep review active:

There's a subtle problem here:
  1. instantiate the client using username, password and auth_url; authenticate is called implicitly.
  2. authentication happens, returning an unscoped token.
  3. code here checks for a scoped token and only sets the management URL if it finds one.
  4. the instantiated client is then returned, seemingly ready to use.
  5. Try to make any other call.
  6. Watch it blow up with an "unsupported operation for string and NoneType" error because it's trying to append the API url fragment to self.management_url which isn't set.
				
Joe Heck		Nov 1
chatting with Gabriel - we need to be able to minimally "list tenants" through the managers so that we can request a tenant-scoped token for usage.
Also exception on no mgmt_url set is horrific and needs to be more sensible.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-08 06:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-08 06:06:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

@gabriel - 

Check out the pathing now for listing tenants with an unscoped token (special cased), and the new general exception for when management_url doesn't exist and resources are requested outside of that special case."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2012-11-08 06:34:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Works for me

I can't really + or - this. Let me explain:

If you want parity with what you can do under the current keystoneclient methods you also have to special-case https://github.com/openstack/python-keystoneclient/blob/master/keystoneclient/v2_0/tokens.py#L24

But if parity is not your goal, then my alternate feedback is that the AccessInfo object doesn't expose enough information. The token I get back from the tokens.authenticate call had a huge amount more information readily available even if it was badly structured.

Again, this depends on goals. If you want parity then AccessInfo needs to expose all the info about the token like it's expiry, etc. as well as the User, the Roles, and all the other data you can get from a Token directly. There's a ton of data shoved into the token.

If you don't want parity that is cool too but that means more impact for projects like Horizon.(FWIW I already have a patch to allow Horizon to work with your code as it is. It's just less pretty.)"}, {'account_id': 6, 'date': '2012-11-09 00:03:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 1816, 'date': '2012-11-09 00:07:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 7: Looks good to me (core reviewer)

commit_message:
removing repeat attempt at authorization in client

blueprint solidify-python-api

* extended and updated documentation strings
* updated README.rst with latest options
* made debug a pass-through value, optionally set on client (instead of
  just being pulled from environment variable)
* adding AccessInfo object and associated tests
  (access.AccessInfo meant to be a cacheable object external to client
  and ultimately to replace service_catalog and it's existing functionality)
* extending authtoken to support lists of endpoints
* maintaining a single entity for client.management_url with first from
  list of possible endpoints
* create project_name and project_id synonyms to match tenant_name and
  tenant_id
* replacing authenticate call to a pure method, not overloading the
  resource/manager path that confuses base URL concepts.
* throw AuthorizationFailure if client attempts to access keystone
  resources before it has a management url
* special case listing tenant using auth_url for unscoped tokens authorized
  through client
* special case listing tokens.authenticate for Dashboard to allow unscoped
  tokens to hand back parity information to dashboard

Change-Id: I4bb3a1b6a5ce2c4b3fbcebeb59116286cac8b2e3

commit_message:
make diagnostics workable for libvirt with Xen

When using "diagnostics" with libvirt as driver on nova-compute
and Xen as hypervisor the call to domain.memoryStats() in
get_diagnostics() doesn't fail with a libvirt.libvirtError,
but with an AttributeError. This exception should be catched, too.

The method virDomainMemoryStats is not implemented in libvirt
for Xen.

fixes bug 1076527

Change-Id: I16645654b346e3c40ff3dd63f20600c802cbeb3f

commit_message:
Changed "Delete volume" success message text

As deletion of volume/snapshot is performed
asynchronous, the success label should not be
'Deleted', but 'Scheduled for deletion', as it
is for Instances ('Scheduled for termination').

Fixes bug 1073718

Change-Id: Ia7884b5b82fea225cfc559309346e73683c4cb3e

I'm also a little concerned about removing os because that removes some key places where greenthreads could previously switch (read, write).  I'm not sure how much of an effect that could have, though."}, {'account_id': 67, 'date': '2012-11-09 01:36:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-07 04:17:13.000000000', 'message': "Fix 401 from auth_token middleware

The openssl popen call to verify the token returns an error code
of 2 when a file doesn't exist. Normally this is caught and the
relevant file is downloaded, but monkeypatching os causes this
error code to be eaten and cinder to return a 401. Note that this
is likely a race condition that depends on exactly when greenthreads
are switching that is causing the return code from Popen to get
overwritten.

It is possible that this is exposing an underlying bug in eventlet
but the workaround is simply to make sure that we don't monkeypatch
os.

Fixes bug 1075838

Change-Id: I69ba75136e32e95c6fdf108f0c4fe21a5e3bdbe6
"}]
commit_message:
Fix 401 from auth_token middleware

The openssl popen call to verify the token returns an error code
of 2 when a file doesn't exist. Normally this is caught and the
relevant file is downloaded, but monkeypatching os causes this
error code to be eaten and cinder to return a 401. Note that this
is likely a race condition that depends on exactly when greenthreads
are switching that is causing the return code from Popen to get
overwritten.

It is possible that this is exposing an underlying bug in eventlet
but the workaround is simply to make sure that we don't monkeypatch
os.

Fixes bug 1075838

Change-Id: I69ba75136e32e95c6fdf108f0c4fe21a5e3bdbe6

use Host: for location rewrites

If the Host header is available, use it for making relative URLs absolute.
Otherwise, continue using SERVER_NAME.

Change-Id: Ifc028264ad1b122a2d5dff9d5528cb369090429f

commit_message:
Remove superfluous slash from admin usage.csv template

The forward-slash is unnecessary in the Admin usage.csv template
and it diverges from the corresponding Project template. This
patch removes it.

Change-Id: I8c1305c0d11bedc3635f41524e8ef62841b70f1a

[{'created': '2012-11-08 20:04:42.000000000', 'message': "show help when calling without arguments

When calling nova without arguments you'll receive the following
output:

error: too few arguments
Try 'nova help ' for more information.

Changing 'and' to 'or' the help is also shown when calling nova
without arguments. I think that's the expected behavior.

Change-Id: Id14f0292ad00e6e45ad66dd010f449c3abbf3871
"}, {'created': '2012-11-08 21:08:09.000000000', 'message': "show help when calling without arguments

commit_message:
show help when calling without arguments

When calling nova without arguments you'll receive the following
output:

error: too few arguments
Try 'nova help ' for more information.

Changing 'and' to 'or' the help is also shown when calling nova
without arguments. I think that's the expected behavior.

Change-Id: Id14f0292ad00e6e45ad66dd010f449c3abbf3871

[{'created': '2012-11-08 22:02:15.000000000', 'message': 'Add a list_stacks RPC call.

This differs from the old show_stack(None) by not resolving stack data.

heat list does not display any of the resolved stack data. Resolving outputs
can be especially slow since FnGetAtt may block while it calls out
to another service (such as with the quantum resources).

Without this change, running heat list on a single Quantum.template takes 1.8s
vs 0.7s.

In the future, list_stacks can be made to support paging of results.

Change-Id: Iae30338b66912d660f1cf48119893b1ab593b67a
'}]
commit_message:
Add a list_stacks RPC call.

This differs from the old show_stack(None) by not resolving stack data.

heat list does not display any of the resolved stack data. Resolving outputs
can be especially slow since FnGetAtt may block while it calls out
to another service (such as with the quantum resources).

Without this change, running heat list on a single Quantum.template takes 1.8s
vs 0.7s.

In the future, list_stacks can be made to support paging of results.

Change-Id: Iae30338b66912d660f1cf48119893b1ab593b67a

commit_message:
show help when calling without arguments

When calling cinder without arguments you'll receive the following
output:

error: too few arguments
Try 'cinder help ' for more information.

Changing 'and' to 'or' the help is also shown when calling cinder
without arguments. I think that's the expected behavior.

Change-Id: Icba257a7c13b3cb36dec9af0d2a29472ea9d78a9

By default, routes.mapper.Mapper.resource adds a bunch of formatted
routes that accept anything after a '.'. Our spec says only .xml
and .json are accepted so limit the formatting to those valuse.

This allows identifiers with a '.' in urls. A few tests were added
to the extensions test to prove that .xml and .json are stripped
but other values are not.

Change-Id: Ic888aa5d75050d6b14763c2a787ac8c8d5ab1f69
"}]
commit_message:
Limit formatting routes when adding resources

By default, routes.mapper.Mapper.resource adds a bunch of formatted
routes that accept anything after a '.'. Our spec says only .xml
and .json are accepted so limit the formatting to those valuse.

This allows identifiers with a '.' in urls. A few tests were added
to the extensions test to prove that .xml and .json are stripped
but other values are not.

Change-Id: Ic888aa5d75050d6b14763c2a787ac8c8d5ab1f69

'}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-09-18 09:06:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: (10 inline comments)

I've outlined some minor problems, but in general the code seems to work as expected. 
I'm more concerned about a problem with editing flavors, which in fact is deleting and creating as new. In this case all extra_specs associated to a flavor are lost(remain connected to the 'deleted' flavor). But for the operators this should be  confusing - editing a flavor clears the extra specs... Maybe there should be some workaround to 'copy' the extra specs on 'Edit' flavor, or some other approach to handle the problem."}, {'account_id': 2455, 'date': '2012-09-18 09:08:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: I would prefer that you didn't merge this

commit_message:
Flavor Extra Specs support.

Special thanks:

  * Preserves extra specs on flavor edit (Tihomir Trifonov)
  * Displays flavor name on extra specs pages (Vinay Bannai)
  * Extras specs table close (Don Dugger & Gabriel).
  * Final cleanup (Gabriel Hurley)

Change-Id: I6acb1176e5c0ca6987abc758fc45335870c55d57

revisions:
[{'created': '2012-11-08 19:43:01.000000000', 'message': "Wrap eventlet's select because I don't trust it.

A bug was filed that showed services using impl_qpid locking up when
trying to connect to qpidd if qpidd was not running when the service was
started.  Digging into python-qpid showed that eventlet's select() was
saying that a pipe was ready for reading before anything had been
written to it, which resulted in doing a read() that blocked forever.

This patch patches the patched select().  It lets eventlet's select() do
its thing, but then does a non-blocking call to the system's built-in
select() to sanity check the result.  It should be harmless and come
with a neglible performance hit.  It does seem to work around the
observed issue.

Work around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I89486aff8c50a247d5a54555af7b95a548ddf38f
"}, {'created': '2012-11-08 19:43:01.000000000', 'message': "Wrap eventlet's select because I don't trust it.

trying to connect to qpidd if qpidd was not running when the service was
started.  Digging into python-qpid showed that eventlet's select() was
saying that a pipe was ready for reading before anything had been
written to it, which resulted in doing a read() that blocked forever.

This patch patches the patched select().  It lets eventlet's select() do
its thing, but then does a non-blocking call to the system's built-in
select() to sanity check the result.  It should be harmless and come
with a neglible performance hit.  It does seem to work around the
observed issue.

Work around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I89486aff8c50a247d5a54555af7b95a548ddf38f
"}, {'created': '2012-11-08 19:43:01.000000000', 'message': "Wrap eventlet's select because I don't trust it.

A bug was filed that showed services using impl_qpid locking up when
trying to connect to qpidd if qpidd was not running when the service was
started.  Digging into python-qpid showed that eventlet's select() was
saying that a pipe was ready for reading before anything had been
written to it, which resulted in doing a read() that blocked forever.

This patch patches the patched select().  It lets eventlet's select() do
its thing, but then does a non-blocking call to the system's built-in
select() to sanity check the result.  It should be harmless and come
with a neglible performance hit.  It does seem to work around the
observed issue.

Work around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I89486aff8c50a247d5a54555af7b95a548ddf38f
"}]
commit_message:
Wrap eventlet's select because I don't trust it.

A bug was filed that showed services using impl_qpid locking up when
trying to connect to qpidd if qpidd was not running when the service was
started.  Digging into python-qpid showed that eventlet's select() was
saying that a pipe was ready for reading before anything had been
written to it, which resulted in doing a read() that blocked forever.

This patch patches the patched select().  It lets eventlet's select() do
its thing, but then does a non-blocking call to the system's built-in
select() to sanity check the result.  It should be harmless and come
with a neglible performance hit.  It does seem to work around the
observed issue.

Work around bug 1073999.

Change-Id: I89486aff8c50a247d5a54555af7b95a548ddf38f

commit_message:
Fix run_tests.sh ambiguous usage msg and behaviour for -x option

In commit
https://github.com/openstack/cinder/commit/
50792c2ff41fdc7e73b3e3c51f4510366debfd14,
the committer wanted to add an option in run_tests.sh for generating XML
coverage report, but ended up accidentally overriding the default nose
option -x. But, the usage message still showed that using option -x will
'Stop running tests after the first error or failure'. So, I changed the
option to generate XML report to  -X (capitalized 'x'). So now both -x and
-X options are available, with different purposes.

Fixes bug 1070047

Change-Id: Ie8c30c14629d4811d6db74f3eea9cdecb1d27c8a

commit_message:
Add documentation for IBM Storwize and SVC

Add a documentation section on the IBM Storwize and SVC volume driver
to the OpenStack Compute Administration Manual.
Create a new sub section in Chapter 11 under "Volume drivers"
that describes how to configure the Storwize and SVC driver.

Minor edits to change "flags" to options and indicate these are
always found in nova.conf.

Change-Id: I202084c868715dff0521158cb73b0614be181b02

commit_message:
Add missing tgt config info to cinder install doc.

The install doc is missing the part about setting up
the persistent tgt files.  Add that, and also while
we're doing that; the default iscsi_helper should now
be tgtadm instead of ietadm.

Change-Id: I8a4bc3b6fa63adde3455af2fa2d81db27bdde4f9
